member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.PixelShaderPipelineStage
member.summary: Pixel Shader pipeline stage.

Bind resources to the output-merger stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D11DeviceContext::OMSetRenderTargetsAndUnorderedAccessViews)
member.param: A collection of ID3D11RenderTargetViews, which represent render-target views. Specify NULL to set none.
A DepthStencilView, which represents a depth-stencil view. Specify NULL to set none.
Index into a zero-based array to begin setting unordered access views (ranges from 0 to D3D11_PS_CS_UAV_REGISTER_COUNT - 1).
A collection of ID3D11UnorderedAccessViews, which represent unordered access views.
An array The number of unordered access views to set.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.OutputMergerPipelineStage.SetRenderTargets(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable`1{Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.RenderTargetView})
member.summary:
Bind one or more render targets atomically and the depth-stencil buffer to the output-merger stage. The depth-stencil state is not bound.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D11DeviceContext::OMSetRenderTargets)
member.param: A collection of render targets (see ) to bind to the device (ranges between 0 and D3D11_SIMULTANEOUS_RENDER_TARGET_COUNT). If this parameter is null, no render targets are bound.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.OutputMergerPipelineStage.SetRenderTargets(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable`1{Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.RenderTargetView},Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.DepthStencilView)
member.summary:
Bind one or more render targets atomically and the depth-stencil buffer to the output-merger stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D11DeviceContext::OMSetRenderTargets)
member.param: A collection of render targets (see ) to bind to the device (ranges between 0 and D3D11_SIMULTANEOUS_RENDER_TARGET_COUNT). If this parameter is null, no render targets are bound.
A depth-stencil view (see ) to bind to the device. If this parameter is null, the depth-stencil state is not bound.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.OutputMergerPipelineStage.SetDepthStencilState(Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.DepthStencilState,System.UInt32)
member.summary:
Sets the depth-stencil state of the output-merger stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D11DeviceContext::OMSetDepthStencilState)
member.param: A depth-stencil state interface (see ) to bind to the device. Set this to NULL to use the default state listed in DepthStencilDescription.
Reference value to perform against when doing a depth-stencil test.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.OutputMergerPipelineStage.SetBlendState(Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.BlendState,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.ColorRgba,System.UInt32)
member.summary:
Set the blend state of the output-merger stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D11DeviceContext::OMSetBlendState)
member.param: A blend-state interface (see ). Passing in NULL implies a default blend state. See remarks for further details.
Four components array of blend factors, one for each RGBA component. This requires a blend state object that specifies the BlendFactor option.
32-bit sample coverage. The default value is 0xffffffff.

remarks.para: Passing in null for the blend-state interface indicates to the runtime to set a default blending state. See the DX SDK (ID3D11Device::OMSetBlendState) for more details about the default blending state.

A sample mask determines which samples get updated in all the active render targets. The mapping of bits in a sample mask to samples in a multisample render target is the responsibility of an individual application. A sample mask is always applied; it is independent of whether multisampling is enabled, and does not depend on whether an application uses multisample render targets.

member.summary: Provides locked access to a rectangular area of the bitmap.
member.param: The rectangle to be accessed.
The access mode you wish to obtain for the lock. This is a bitwise combination of BitmapLockFlags for read, write, or read and write access.
member.returns: A WICBitmapLock object that represents locked memory location.
member.remarks: Locks are exclusive for writing but can be shared for reading. You cannot call BitmapSource.CopyPixels() while the WICBitmap is locked for writing. Doing so will return an error, since locks are exclusive.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.Surface1.ReleaseDC(Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D.D3dRect)
member.summary:
Releases the GDI device context (DC) associated with the current surface and allows rendering using Direct3D.
(Also see DirectX SDK: IDXGISurface1::ReleaseDC)
member.param: A RECT structure that identifies the dirty region of the surface. A dirty region is any part of the surface that you have used for GDI rendering and that you want to preserve. This is used as a performance hint to graphics subsystem in certain scenarios. Do not use this parameter to restrict rendering to the specified rectangular region. Passing in NULL causes the whole surface to be considered dirty. Otherwise the area specified by the RECT will be used as a performance hint to indicate what areas have been manipulated by GDI rendering.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.Surface1.GetDC(System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Returns a device context (DC) that allows you to render to a DXGI surface using GDI.
(Also see DirectX SDK: IDXGISurface1::GetDC)
member.param: If true the application will not preserve any rendering with GDI; otherwise, false. If false, any previous rendering to the device context will be preserved. This flag is ideal for simply reading the device context and not doing any rendering to the surface.
member.returns: A HDC handle that represents the current device context for GDI rendering.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.Surface1
member.summary:
The Surface1 interface extends the Surface by adding support for rendering to a DXGI interface using GDI.
(Also see DirectX SDK: IDXGISurface1)

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.KeyedMutex.ReleaseSync(System.UInt64)
member.summary:
Using a key, releases exclusive rendering access to a shared resource
(Also see DirectX SDK: IDXGIKeyedMutex::ReleaseSync)
member.param: A value that indicates which device to give access to. This method will succeed when the device that currently owns the surface calls the KeyedMutex.ReleaseSync method using the same value. This value can be any UINT64 value.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.KeyedMutex.AcquireSync(System.UInt64,System.UInt32!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsLong)
member.summary:
Using a key, acquires exclusive rendering access to a shared resource.
(Also see DirectX SDK: IDXGIKeyedMutex::AcquireSync)
member.param: A value that indicates which device to give access to. This method will succeed when the device that currently owns the surface calls the KeyedMutex.ReleaseSync method using the same value. This value can be any UINT64 value.

The time-out interval, in milliseconds. This method will return if the interval elapses, and the keyed mutex has not been released using the specified Key. If this value is set to zero, the AcquireSync method will test to see if the keyed mutex has been released and returns immediately. If this value is set to INFINITE, the time-out interval will never elapse.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.KeyedMutex
member.summary:
Represents a keyed mutex, which allows exclusive access to a shared resource that is used by multiple devices.
(Also see DirectX SDK: IDXGIKeyedMutex)

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectHelpers.CreateInterface``1(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Create a wrapper for a given native interface pointer that does not have an IUnknown. This method will not increase the ref count for the wrapped native interface. Also, when this class is disposed, the native interface will not be deleted or released. This method is mainly intended to wrap interfaces that do not inherit from IUnknown.
member.typeparam: The type of the object wrapper to create. Must inherit from .
member.param: The native pointer to the interface.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectHelpers.CreateIUnknown``1(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Create a wrapper for a given native IUnknown interface pointer. This method will not increase the ref count for the wrapped native interface. However, when this class is disposed, the native interface will have Release() called. This method is mainly intended to wrap interfaces that inherit from IUnknown.
member.param: The native pointer to the IUnknown interface.
member.typeparam: The type of the IUnknown wrapper to create. Must inherit from .

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.InputAssemblerPipelineStage.SetVertexBuffers(System.UInt32,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable`1{Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.D3DBuffer},System.UInt32[],System.UInt32[])
member.summary:
Bind an array of vertex buffers to the input-assembler stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetVertexBuffers)
member.param: The first input slot for binding. The first vertex buffer is explicitly bound to the start slot; this causes each additional vertex buffer in the array to be implicitly bound to each subsequent input slot. There are 16 input slots (ranges from 0 to D3D11_IA_VERTEX_INPUT_RESOURCE_SLOT_COUNT - 1).

A collection of vertex buffers (see ). The number of buffers (plus the starting slot) cannot exceed the total number of IA-stage input slots (ranges from 0 to D3D11_IA_VERTEX_INPUT_RESOURCE_SLOT_COUNT - startSlot). The vertex buffers must have been created with the VertexBuffer flag.
An array of stride values; one stride value for each buffer in the vertex-buffer array. Each stride is the size (in bytes) of the elements that are to be used from that vertex buffer.

An array of offset values; one offset value for each buffer in the vertex-buffer array. Each offset is the number of bytes between the first element of a vertex buffer and the first element that will be used.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.InputAssemblerPipelineStage.SetPrimitiveTopology(<unknown type>)
member.summary:
Bind information about the primitive type, and data order that describes input data for the input assembler stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetPrimitiveTopology)
member.param: The type of primitive and ordering of the primitive data (see ).

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.InputAssemblerPipelineStage.SetInputLayout(Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.InputLayout)
member.summary:
Bind an input-layout object to the input-assembler stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetInputLayout)
member.param: The input-layout object (see ), which describes the input buffers that will be read by the IA stage.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.InputAssemblerPipelineStage.SetIndexBuffer(Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.D3DBuffer,<unknown type>,System.UInt32)
member.summary:
Bind an index buffer to the input-assembler stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetIndexBuffer)
member.param: A D3DBuffer object, that contains indices. The index buffer must have been created with the indexBuffer flag.
A Format that specifies the format of the data in the index buffer. The only formats allowed for index buffer data are 16-bit (Format_R16_UINT) and 32-bit (Format_R32_UINT) integers.
Offset (in bytes) from the start of the index buffer to the first index to use.
member.remarks: Calling this method using a buffer that is currently bound for writing (i.e. bound to the stream output pipeline stage) will effectively bind null instead because a buffer cannot be bound as both an input and an output at the same time.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.InputAssemblerPipelineStage.GetVertexBuffers(System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.UInt32[]@,System.UInt32[]@)
member.summary:
Get the vertex buffers bound to the input-assembler stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D11DeviceContext::IAGetVertexBuffers)
member.param: The input slot of the first vertex buffer to get. The first vertex buffer is explicitly bound to the start slot; this causes each additional vertex buffer in the array to be implicitly bound to each subsequent input slot. There are 16 input slots.
The number of vertex buffers to get starting at the offset. The number of buffers (plus the starting slot) cannot exceed the total number of IA-stage input slots.

A collection of stride values returned by the method; one stride value for each buffer in the vertex-buffer array. Each stride value is the size (in bytes) of the elements that are to be used from that vertex buffer.

A collection of offset values returned by the method; one offset value for each buffer in the vertex-buffer array. Each offset is the number of bytes between the first element of a vertex buffer and the first element that will be used.
member.returns: A collection of vertex buffers returned by the method (see ).

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.InputAssemblerPipelineStage.GetPrimitiveTopology
member.summary:
Get information about the primitive type, and data order that describes input data for the input assembler stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D11DeviceContext::IAGetPrimitiveTopology)
member.returns: The type of primitive, and ordering of the primitive data (see ).

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.InputAssemblerPipelineStage.GetInputLayout
member.summary:
Get the input-layout object that is bound to the input-assembler stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D11DeviceContext::IAGetInputLayout)
member.returns: The input-layout object (see ), which describes the input buffers that will be read by the IA stage.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.InputAssemblerPipelineStage.GetIndexBuffer(<unknown type>@,System.UInt32@)
member.summary:
Get the index buffer that is bound to the input-assembler stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D11DeviceContext::IAGetIndexBuffer)
member.param: The format of the data in the index buffer (see ). These formats provide the size and type of the data in the buffer. The only formats allowed for index buffer data are 16-bit (Format_R16_UINT) and 32-bit (Format_R32_UINT) integers.
Offset (in bytes) from the start of the index buffer, to the first index to use.
member.returns: An index buffer returned by the method (see ).

member.summary: InputAssembler pipeline stage.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.Output.FindClosestMatchingMode(Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.ModeDescription)
member.summary:
Find the display mode that most closely matches the requested display mode.
(Also see DirectX SDK: IDXGIOutput::FindClosestMatchingMode)
member.param: The desired display mode (see ). Members of ModeDescription can be unspecified indicating no preference for that member. A value of 0 for Width or Height indicates the value is unspecified. If either Width or Height are 0 both must be 0. A numerator and denominator of 0 in RefreshRate indicate it is unspecified. Other members of ModeDescription have enumeration values indicating the member is unspecified. Format cannot be UNKNOWN.
member.returns: The mode that most closely matches ModeToMatch.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.Output.FindClosestMatchingMode(Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.ModeDescription,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.D3DDevice)
member.summary:
Find the display mode that most closely matches the requested display mode for a given Direct3D Device.
(Also see DirectX SDK: IDXGIOutput::FindClosestMatchingMode)
member.param: The desired display mode (see ). Members of ModeDescription can be unspecified indicating no preference for that member. A value of 0 for Width or Height indicates the value is unspecified. If either Width or Height are 0 both must be 0. A numerator and denominator of 0 in RefreshRate indicate it is unspecified. Other members of ModeDescription have enumeration values indicating the member is unspecified. If pConnectedDevice is null, Format cannot be UNKNOWN.

The Direct3D device object. If this parameter is NULL, only modes whose format matches that of pModeToMatch will be returned; otherwise, only those formats that are supported for scan-out by the device are returned.
member.returns: The mode that most closely matches ModeToMatch.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.Output.FindClosestMatchingMode(Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.ModeDescription,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.D3DDevice)
member.summary:
Find the display mode that most closely matches the requested display mode for a given Direct3D Device.
(Also see DirectX SDK: IDXGIOutput::FindClosestMatchingMode)
member.param: The desired display mode (see ). Members of ModeDescription can be unspecified indicating no preference for that member. A value of 0 for Width or Height indicates the value is unspecified. If either Width or Height are 0 both must be 0. A numerator and denominator of 0 in RefreshRate indicate it is unspecified. Other members of ModeDescription have enumeration values indicating the member is unspecified. If pConnectedDevice is null, Format cannot be UNKNOWN.

The Direct3D device object. If this parameter is NULL, only modes whose format matches that of pModeToMatch will be returned; otherwise, only those formats that are supported for scan-out by the device are returned.
member.returns: The mode that most closely matches ModeToMatch.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TextLayout.HitTestTextRange(System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: The application calls this function to get a set of hit-test metrics corresponding to a range of text positions. The main usage for this is to draw highlighted selection of the text string.
member.param: First text position of the specified range.
Number of positions of the specified range.
Offset of the X origin (left of the layout box) which is added to each of the hit-test metrics returned.
Offset of the Y origin (top of the layout box) which is added to each of the hit-test metrics returned.
member.returns: Aarray of the output geometry fully enclosing the specified position range.
member.remarks: There are no gaps in the returned metrics. While there could be visual gaps, depending on bidi ordering, each range is contiguous and reports all the text, including any hidden characters and trimmed text. The height of each returned range will be the same within each line, regardless of how the font sizes vary.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TextLayout.HitTestTextPosition(System.UInt32,System.Boolean,System.Single@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Given a text position and whether the caret is on the leading or trailing edge of that position, this returns the corresponding coordinate (in DIPs) relative to the top-left of the layout box. This is most useful for drawing the caret's current position, but it could also be used to anchor an IME to the typed text or attach a floating menu near the point of interest. It may also be used to programmatically obtain the geometry of a particular text position for UI automation.
member.param: Text position to get the coordinate of.
Flag indicating whether the location is of the leading or the trailing side of the specified text position.
Output caret X, relative to the top-left of the layout box.
Output caret Y, relative to the top-left of the layout box.
member.returns: Output geometry fully enclosing the specified text position.
member.remarks: When drawing a caret at the returned X,Y, it should should be centered on X and drawn from the Y coordinate down. The height will be the size of the hit-tested text (which can vary in size within a line). Reading direction also affects which side of the character the caret is drawn. However, the returned X coordinate will be correct for either case. You can get a text length back that is larger than a single character. This happens for complex scripts when multiple characters form a single cluster, when diacritics join their base character, or when you test a surrogate pair.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TextLayout.HitTestPoint(System.Single,System.Single,System.Boolean@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Given a coordinate (in DIPs) relative to the top-left of the layout box, this returns the corresponding hit-test metrics of the text string where the hit-test has occurred. This is useful for mapping mouse clicks to caret positions. When the given coordinate is outside the text string, the function sets the output value *isInside to false but returns the nearest character position.
member.param: X coordinate to hit-test, relative to the top-left location of the layout box.
Y coordinate to hit-test, relative to the top-left location of the layout box.
Output flag indicating whether the hit-test location is inside the text string. When false, the position nearest the text's edge is returned.

Output flag indicating whether the hit-test location is at the leading or the trailing side of the character. When the output *isInside value is set to false, this value is set according to the output *position value to represent the edge closest to the hit-test location.
member.returns: Output geometry fully enclosing the hit-test location. When the output isInside value is set to false, this structure represents the geometry enclosing the edge closest to the hit-test location.

member.name: P:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TextLayout.OverhangMetrics
member.summary: GetOverhangMetrics returns the overhangs (in DIPs) of the layout and all objects contained in it, including text glyphs and inline objects.
member.remarks: Any underline and strikethrough do not contribute to the black box determination, since these are actually drawn by the renderer, which is allowed to draw them in any variety of styles.

member.name: P:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TextLayout.Metrics
member.summary: Retrieves overall metrics for the formatted string.
member.remarks: Drawing effects like underline and strikethrough do not contribute to the text size, which is essentially the sum of advance widths and line heights. Additionally, visible swashes and other graphic adornments may extend outside the returned width and height.

member.summary: The application may call this function to create an inline object for trimming, using an ellipsis as the omission sign. The ellipsis will be created using the current settings of the format, including base font, style, and any effects. Alternate omission signs can be created by the application by implementing ICustomInlineObject.
member.param: The format to use for settings.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.DWriteFactory.CreateGdiCompatibleTextLayout(System.String,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TextFormat,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Boolean)
member.summary: CreateGdiCompatibleTextLayout takes a string, format, and associated constraints and produces and object representing the result formatted for a particular display resolution and measuring method. The resulting text layout should only be used for the intended resolution, and for cases where text scalability is desired, CreateTextLayout should be used instead.
member.param: The characters to layout.
The format to apply to the string.
Width of the layout box.
Height of the layout box.
Number of physical pixels per DIP. For example, if rendering onto a 96 DPI device then pixelsPerDip is 1. If rendering onto a 120 DPI device then pixelsPerDip is 120/96.

When set to False, instructs the text layout to use the same metrics as GDI aliased text. When set to True, instructs the text layout to use the same metrics as text measured by GDI using a font created with CleartypeNaturalQuality.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.DWriteFactory.CreateGdiCompatibleTextLayout(System.String,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TextFormat,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Boolean,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.Matrix3x2F)
member.summary: CreateGdiCompatibleTextLayout takes a string, format, and associated constraints and produces and object representing the result formatted for a particular display resolution and measuring method. The resulting text layout should only be used for the intended resolution, and for cases where text scalability is desired, CreateTextLayout should be used instead.
member.param: The characters to layout.
The format to apply to the string.
Width of the layout box.
Height of the layout box.
Number of physical pixels per DIP. For example, if rendering onto a 96 DPI device then pixelsPerDip is 1. If rendering onto a 120 DPI device then pixelsPerDip is 120/96.
Transform applied to the glyphs and their positions. This transform is applied after the scaling specified the font size and pixelsPerDip.

When set to False, instructs the text layout to use the same metrics as GDI aliased text. When set to True, instructs the text layout to use the same metrics as text measured by GDI using a font created with NaturalQuality.

A debug interface controls debug settings, validates pipeline state and can only be used if the debug layer is turned on.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D10Debug)

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.InputAssemblerPipelineStage.SetVertexBuffers(System.UInt32,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable`1{Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.D3DBuffer},System.UInt32[],System.UInt32[])
member.summary:
Bind an array of vertex buffers to the input-assembler stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D10Device::IASetVertexBuffers)
member.param: The first input slot for binding. The first vertex buffer is explicitly bound to the start slot; this causes each additional vertex buffer in the array to be implicitly bound to each subsequent input slot. There are 16 input slots (ranges from 0 to D3D10_IA_VERTEX_INPUT_RESOURCE_SLOT_COUNT - 1).

A collection of vertex buffers (see ). The number of buffers (plus the starting slot) cannot exceed the total number of IA-stage input slots (ranges from 0 to D3D10_IA_VERTEX_INPUT_RESOURCE_SLOT_COUNT - startSlot). The vertex buffers must have been created with the VertexBuffer flag.
An array of stride values; one stride value for each buffer in the vertex-buffer array. Each stride is the size (in bytes) of the elements that are to be used from that vertex buffer.

An array of offset values; one offset value for each buffer in the vertex-buffer array. Each offset is the number of bytes between the first element of a vertex buffer and the first element that will be used.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.InputAssemblerPipelineStage.SetPrimitiveTopology(<unknown type>)
member.summary:
Bind information about the primitive type, and data order that describes input data for the input assembler stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D10Device::IASetPrimitiveTopology)
member.param: The type of primitive and ordering of the primitive data (see ).

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.InputAssemblerPipelineStage.SetInputLayout(Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.InputLayout)
member.summary:
Bind an input-layout object to the input-assembler stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D10Device::IASetInputLayout)
member.param: The input-layout object (see ), which describes the input buffers that will be read by the IA stage.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.InputAssemblerPipelineStage.SetIndexBuffer(Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.D3DBuffer,<unknown type>,System.UInt32)
member.summary:
Bind an index buffer to the input-assembler stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D10Device::IASetIndexBuffer)
member.param: A D3DBuffer object, that contains indices. The index buffer must have been created with the indexBuffer flag.
A Format that specifies the format of the data in the index buffer. The only formats allowed for index buffer data are 16-bit (Format_R16_UINT) and 32-bit (Format_R32_UINT) integers.
Offset (in bytes) from the start of the index buffer to the first index to use.
member.remarks: Calling this method using a buffer that is currently bound for writing (i.e. bound to the stream output pipeline stage) will effectively bind null instead because a buffer cannot be bound as both an input and an output at the same time.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.InputAssemblerPipelineStage.GetVertexBuffers(System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.UInt32[]@,System.UInt32[]@)
member.summary:
Get the vertex buffers bound to the input-assembler stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D10Device::IAGetVertexBuffers)
member.param: The input slot of the first vertex buffer to get. The first vertex buffer is explicitly bound to the start slot; this causes each additional vertex buffer in the array to be implicitly bound to each subsequent input slot. There are 16 input slots.
The number of vertex buffers to get starting at the offset. The number of buffers (plus the starting slot) cannot exceed the total number of IA-stage input slots.

A collection of stride values returned by the method; one stride value for each buffer in the vertex-buffer array. Each stride value is the size (in bytes) of the elements that are to be used from that vertex buffer.

A collection of offset values returned by the method; one offset value for each buffer in the vertex-buffer array. Each offset is the number of bytes between the first element of a vertex buffer and the first element that will be used.
member.returns: A collection of vertex buffers returned by the method (see ).

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.InputAssemblerPipelineStage.GetPrimitiveTopology
member.summary:
Get information about the primitive type, and data order that describes input data for the input assembler stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D10Device::IAGetPrimitiveTopology)
member.returns: The type of primitive, and ordering of the primitive data (see ).

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.InputAssemblerPipelineStage.GetInputLayout
member.summary:
Get the input-layout object that is bound to the input-assembler stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D10Device::IAGetInputLayout)
member.returns: The input-layout object (see ), which describes the input buffers that will be read by the IA stage.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.InputAssemblerPipelineStage.GetIndexBuffer(<unknown type>@,System.UInt32@)
member.summary:
Get the index buffer that is bound to the input-assembler stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D10Device::IAGetIndexBuffer)
member.param: The format of the data in the index buffer (see ). These formats provide the size and type of the data in the buffer. The only formats allowed for index buffer data are 16-bit (Format_R16_UINT) and 32-bit (Format_R32_UINT) integers.
Offset (in bytes) from the start of the index buffer, to the first index to use.
member.returns: An index buffer returned by the method (see ).

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.D3DDevice1.CreateDevice1(Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.Adapter,<unknown type>,System.String,<unknown type>,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D.FeatureLevel)
member.summary:
Create a Direct3D 10.1 device.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10CreateDevice1() function)
member.param: An Adapter object. Can be null.
The type of driver for the device.
Device creation flags that enable API layers. These flags can be bitwise OR'd together.
A path the DLL that implements a software rasterizer. Must be NULL if driverType is non-software.
The highest hardware feature level supported by this device.
member.remarks: By default, all Direct3D 10 calls are handled in a thread-safe way. By creating a single-threaded device (using .SingleThreaded), you disable thread-safe calling.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.D3DDevice1.CreateDevice1
member.summary:
Create a Direct3D 10.1 device using the default hardware adapter and the most common settings.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10CreateDevice1() function)
member.remarks: If DirectX SDK environment variable is found, and the build is a Debug one, this method will attempt to use .Debug flag. This should allow using the InfoQueue object.

member.summary:
Create a Direct3D 10.1 device and a swap chain.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10CreateDeviceAndSwapChain1() function)
member.param: An Adapter object. Can be null.
The type of driver for the device.
A path the DLL that implements a software rasterizer. Must be NULL if driverType is non-software.
Device creation flags that enable API layers. These flags can be bitwise OR'd together.
The feature level supported by this device.
Description of the swap chain.
The created SwapChain object.
member.remarks: By default, all Direct3D 10 calls are handled in a thread-safe way. By creating a single-threaded device (using .SingleThreaded), you disable thread-safe calling.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.D3DDevice1.CreateDeviceAndSwapChain1(System.IntPtr,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.SwapChain@)
member.summary:
Create a Direct3D 10.1 device and a swap chain using the default hardware adapter and the most common settings.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10CreateDeviceAndSwapChain1() function)
member.param: The window handle to the output window.
The created SwapChain object.
member.remarks: If DirectX SDK environment variable is found, and the build is a Debug one, this method will attempt to use .Debug flag. This should allow using the InfoQueue object.

member.summary:
The device interface represents a virtual adapter for Direct3D 10.1; it is used to perform rendering and create Direct3D resources.
To create a D3DDevice1 instance, use one of the static factory method overloads: CreateDevice1() or CreateDeviceAndSwapChain1().
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D10Device1)

member.summary: A palette that has 256 shades of gray.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.WindowsImagingComponent.BitmapPaletteType.FixedHalftone252
member.summary: A palette that has its 252-color on-off primaries and the 16 system colors added. With duplicates removed, 256 colors are available.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.WindowsImagingComponent.BitmapPaletteType.FixedWebPalette
member.summary: A palette that has 6 intensity levels of each primary: 216-color on-off primaries and the 16 system colors added. With duplicates removed, 224 colors are available. This is the same as FixedHalftone216.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.WindowsImagingComponent.BitmapPaletteType.FixedHalftone216
member.summary: A palette that has 6 intensity levels of each primary: 216-color on-off primaries and the 16 system colors added. With duplicates removed, 224 colors are available. This is the same as FixedWebPalette.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.WindowsImagingComponent.BitmapPaletteType.FixedHalftone125
member.summary: A palette that has 5 intensity levels of each primary: 125-color on-off primaries and the 16 system colors added. With duplicates removed, 133 colors are available.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.WindowsImagingComponent.BitmapPaletteType.FixedHalftone64
member.summary: A palette that has 4 intensity levels of each primary: 64-color on-off primaries and the 16 system colors added. With duplicates removed, 72 colors are available.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.WindowsImagingComponent.BitmapPaletteType.FixedHalftone27
member.summary: A palette that has 3 intensity levels of each primary: 27-color on-off primaries and the 16 system colors added. With duplicates removed, 35 colors are available.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.WindowsImagingComponent.BitmapPaletteType.FixedHalftone8
member.summary: A palette that has its 8-color on-off primaries and the 16 system colors added. With duplicates removed, 16 colors are available.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.WindowsImagingComponent.BitmapPaletteType.FixedBW
member.summary: A black and white palette.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.WindowsImagingComponent.BitmapPaletteType.MedianCut

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.WindowsImagingComponent.BitmapPaletteType.Custom

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.StreamOutputPipelineStage.SetTargets(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable`1{Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.D3DBuffer},System.UInt32[])
member.summary:
Set the target output buffers for the stream-output stage of the pipeline.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D11DeviceContext::SOSetTargets)
member.param: The collection of output buffers (see ) to bind to the device. The buffers must have been created with the StreamOutput flag. A maximum of four output buffers can be set. If less than four are defined by the call, the remaining buffer slots are set to NULL.
Array of offsets to the output buffers from ppBuffers, one offset for each buffer. The offset values must be in bytes.

member.param: A collection of scissor rectangles (see ).

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.RasterizerPipelineStage.GetViewports(System.UInt32)
member.summary:
Get the array of viewports bound to the rasterizer stage
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D11DeviceContext::RSGetViewports)
member.param: The input specifies the maximum number of viewports (ranges from 0 to D3D11_VIEWPORT_AND_SCISSORRECT_OBJECT_COUNT_PER_PIPELINE) to retrieve, the output contains the actual number of viewports returned.
member.returns: A collection of Viewport structures that are bound to the device. If the number of viewports (in maxNumberOfViewports) is greater than the actual number of viewports currently bound, then the collection will be trimmed to contain only the currently bound. See the structure page for details about how the viewport size is dependent on the device feature level which has changed between Direct3D 11 and Direct3D 10.

member.summary:
Get the collection of scissor rectangles bound to the rasterizer stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D11DeviceContext::RSGetScissorRects)
member.returns: A collection of scissor rectangles (see ). If maximumNumberOfRects is greater than the number of scissor rects currently bound, then the collection will be trimmed to contain only the currently bound.

member.summary:

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.OutputMergerPipelineStage.SetBlendState(Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.BlendState,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.ColorRgba,System.UInt32)
member.summary:
Set the blend state of the output-merger stage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID3D10Device::OMSetBlendState)
member.param: A blend-state interface (see ). Passing in NULL implies a default blend state. See remarks for further details.
Four components array of blend factors, one for each RGBA component. This requires a blend state object that specifies the BlendFactor option.
32-bit sample coverage. The default value is 0xffffffff.

remarks.para: Passing in null for the blend-state interface indicates to the runtime to set a default blending state. See the DX SDK (ID3D10Device::OMSetBlendState) for more details about the default blending state.

A sample mask determines which samples get updated in all the active render targets. The mapping of bits in a sample mask to samples in a multisample render target is the responsibility of an individual application. A sample mask is always applied; it is independent of whether multisampling is enabled, and does not depend on whether an application uses multisample render targets.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.PathGeometry.Open
member.summary:
Opens a geometry sink that will be used to create this path geometry.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID2D1PathGeometry::Open)
member.returns: Returns the geometry sink that is used to populate the path geometry with figures and segments.
member.remarks:
Because path geometries are immutable and can only be populated once, it is an error to call Open on a path geometry more than once.
Note that the fill mode defaults to Alternate. To set the fill mode, call SetFillMode before the first call to BeginFigure. Failure to do so will put the geometry sink in an error state.

(Also see DirectX SDK: ID2D1SimplifiedGeometrySink::AddBeziers)
member.param: A collection of of Bezier segments that describes the Bezier curves to create. A curve is drawn from the geometry sink's current point (the end point of the last segment drawn or the location specified by BeginFigure) to the end point of the first Bezier segment in the array. If the collection contains additional Bezier segments, each subsequent Bezier segment uses the end point of the preceding Bezier segment as its start point.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.SimplifiedGeometrySink.AddLines(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable`1{Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.Point2F})
member.summary:
Creates a sequence of lines using the specified points and adds them to the geometry sink.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID2D1SimplifiedGeometrySink::AddLines)
member.param: A collection of one or more points that describe the lines to draw. A line is drawn from the geometry sink's current point (the end point of the last segment drawn or the location specified by BeginFigure) to the first point in the array. if the array contains additional points, a line is drawn from the first point to the second point in the array, from the second point to the third point, and so on.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.Geometry.ComputePointAtLength(System.Single,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.Point2F@)
member.summary:
Calculates the point and tangent vector at the specified distance along the geometry after it has been transformed by the specified matrix and flattened using the default tolerance.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID2D1Geometry::ComputePointAtLength)
member.param: The distance along the geometry of the point and tangent to find. If this distance is less then 0, this method calculates the first point in the geometry. If this distance is greater than the length of the geometry, this method calculates the last point in the geometry.
When this method returns, contains a pointer to the tangent vector at the specified distance along the geometry. If the geometry is empty, this vector contains NaN as its x and y values.
member.returns: The location at the specified distance along the geometry. If the geometry is empty, this point contains NaN as its x and y values.

member.summary:
Ends drawing on the render target, error results can be retrieved at this time, or when calling Flush() or TryFlush().
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID2D1RenderTarget::EndDraw)
member.param: The associated tags.
The associated tags.
member.returns: True if successful; False otherwise. If unsuccessful, the tags and errorCode parameters should be used to find out which operation has failed.
member.remarks: This method does not throw Direct2D exceptions if a drawing error occur while rendering shapes.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTarget.EndDraw
member.summary:

(Also see DirectX SDK: ID2D1RenderTarget::EndDraw)

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTarget.BeginDraw
member.summary:

(Also see DirectX SDK: ID2D1RenderTarget::BeginDraw)

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTarget.Clear
member.summary:
Clears the drawing area to transparent black.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID2D1RenderTarget::Clear)

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTarget.Clear(Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.ColorF)
member.summary:
Clears the drawing area to the specified color.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID2D1RenderTarget::Clear)
member.remarks: For render targets that support alpha, the clearColor is treated as straight alpha, regardless of whether the alpha mode is straight alpha or premultiplied alpha. For targets that ignore alpha, the alpha of the clear color is interpreted as fully opaque. If the render target has an active clip (specified by PushAxisAlignedClip), the clear command is only applied to the area within the clip region.
member.param: The clearColor parameter.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTarget.PopAxisAlignedClip
member.summary:
Removes the last axis-aligned clip from the render target. After this method is called, the clip is no longer applied to subsequent drawing operations.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID2D1RenderTarget::PopAxisAlignedClip)
member.remarks: A PushAxisAlignedClip/PopAxisAlignedClip pair can occur around or within a PushLayer/PopLayer pair, but may not overlap. For example, a PushAxisAlignedClip, PushLayer, PopLayer, PopAxisAlignedClip sequence is valid, but a PushAxisAlignedClip, PushLayer, PopAxisAlignedClip, PopLayer sequence is not. PopAxisAlignedClip must be called once for every call to PushAxisAlignedClip.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTarget.PushAxisAlignedClip(Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RectF,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.AntialiasMode)
member.summary:
Pushes a clip. The clip can be antialiased. The clip must be axis aligned. If the current world transform is not axis preserving, then the bounding box of the transformed clip rect will be used. The clip will remain in effect until a PopAxisAligned clip call is made.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID2D1RenderTarget::PushAxisAlignedClip)
member.param: The clipRect parameter.
The antialiasMode parameter.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTarget.GetGdiInteropRenderTarget
member.summary: Provide a GdiInteropRenderTarget version of this render target.
member.remarks: Not all render targets support . The render target must be GDI-compatible (the RenderTargetUsage.GdiCompatible flag was specified when creating the render target), use the DXGI's Format.B8G8R8A8_UNORM pixel format, and use the AlphaMode.Premultiplied or AlphaMode.Ignore alpha mode. Note that this method always succeeds; if the render target doesn't support the GdiInteropRenderTarget interface, calling GetDC will fail. (For render targets created through the CreateCompatibleRenderTarget method, the render target that created it must have these settings.) To test whether a given render target supports GdiInteropRenderTarget, create a that specifies GDI compatibility and the appropriate pixel format, then call the render target's IsSupported property to see whether the render target is GDI-compatible.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTarget.FillOpacityMask(Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.D2DBitmap,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.Brush,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.OpacityMaskContent)
member.summary:
Fill using the opacity channel of the supplied bitmap as a mask. The alpha channel of the bitmap is used to represent the coverage of the geometry at each pixel, and this is filled appropriately with the brush. The render target antialiasing mode must be set to aliased. The brush paints a rectangle the same size as the opacityMask bitmap and positioned on the origin.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID2D1RenderTarget::FillOpacityMask)
member.param: The opacity mask to apply to the brush. The alpha value of each pixel in the region specified by sourceRectangle is multiplied with the alpha value of the brush after the brush has been mapped to the area defined by destinationRectangle.
The brush used to paint the region of the render target specified by destinationRectangle.
The type of contain the opacity mask contains. The value is used to determine the color space in which the opacity mask is blended.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTarget.CreateLayer
member.summary:
Creates a layer resource that can be used on any target and which will resize under the covers if necessary. The size will be unspecified so the returned resource is a placeholder and the backing store will be allocated to be the minimum size that can hold the content when the layer is pushed.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID2D1RenderTarget::CreateLayer)

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTarget.CreateLayer(Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.SizeF)
member.summary:
Creates a layer resource that can be used on any target and which will resize under the covers if necessary. Use this overload to prevent unwanted reallocation of the layer backing store. The size is in DIPs, but, it is unaffected by the current world transform.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID2D1RenderTarget::CreateLayer)
member.param: The resolution independent minimum size hint for the layer resource.

Create a D2D bitmap by sharing bits from another resource. The bitmap must be compatible with the render target for the call to succeed. For example, a WICBitmapLock can be shared with a software target, or a DXGI surface can be shared with a DXGI render target.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID2D1RenderTarget::CreateSharedBitmap)
member.param: The wicBitmap.
The bitmap properties.

member.summary:

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.D2DBitmap.CopyFromMemory(System.Byte[],System.UInt32)
member.summary:
Copies the specified region from memory into the current bitmap.
(Also see DirectX SDK: ID2D1Bitmap::CopyFromMemory)
member.param: The data to copy.

The stride, or pitch, of the source bitmap stored in srcData. The stride is the byte count of a scanline (one row of pixels in memory). The stride can be computed from the following formula: pixel width * bytes per pixel + memory padding.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.GlyphRun.BidiLevel
member.summary: The implicit resolved bidi level of the run. Odd levels indicate right-to-left languages like Hebrew and Arabic, while even levels indicate left-to-right languages like English and Japanese (when written horizontally). For right-to-left languages, the text origin is on the right, and text should be drawn to the left.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.GlyphRun.IsSideways
member.summary: If true, specifies that glyphs are rotated 90 degrees to the left and vertical metrics are used. Vertical writing is achieved by specifying isSideways = true and rotating the entire run 90 degrees to the right via a rotate transform.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.GlyphRun.GlyphOffsets
member.summary: Glyph offsets.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.GlyphRun.GlyphAdvances
member.summary: Glyph advance widths.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.GlyphRun.GlyphIndices
member.summary: The indices to render.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.GlyphRun.FontEmSize
member.summary: Logical size of the font in DIPs, not points (equals 1/96 inch).

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.GlyphRun.FontFace
member.summary: The physical font face to draw with.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.GlyphRun
member.summary: Contains the information needed by renderers to draw glyph runs. All coordinates are in device independent pixels (DIPs).

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.GlyphOffset.AscenderOffset
member.summary: Offset in the ascent direction, i.e., the direction ascenders point. A positive ascender offset moves the glyph up (in pre-transform coordinates).

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.GlyphOffset.AdvanceOffset
member.summary: Offset in the advance direction of the run. A positive advance offset moves the glyph to the right (in pre-transform coordinates) if the run is left-to-right or to the left if the run is right-to-left.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.GlyphOffset.#ctor(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Constructor for FontFeature

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.GlyphOffset
member.summary: Optional adjustment to a glyph's position. An glyph offset changes the position of a glyph without affecting the pen position. Offsets are in logical, pre-transform units.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.GlyphMetrics.VerticalOriginY
member.summary: Specifies the Y coordinate of a glyph's vertical origin, in the font's design coordinate system. The y coordinate of a glyph's vertical origin is the sum of the glyph's top side bearing and the top (i.e. yMax) of the glyph's bounding box.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.GlyphMetrics.BottomSideBearing
member.summary: Specifies the vertical distance from the black box's bottom edge to the advance height. Positive when the bottom edge of the black box is within the layout box. Negative when the bottom edge of black box overhangs the layout box.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.GlyphMetrics.AdvanceHeight
member.summary: Specifies the Y offset from the vertical origin of the current glyph to the vertical origin of the next glyph when writing vertically. (Note that the term "origin" by itself denotes the horizontal origin. The vertical origin is different. Its Y coordinate is specified by verticalOriginY value, and its X coordinate is half the advanceWidth to the right of the horizontal origin).

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.GlyphMetrics.TopSideBearing
member.summary: Specifies the vertical offset from the vertical origin to the top of the black box. Thus, a positive value adds whitespace whereas a negative value means the glyph overhangs the top of the layout box.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.GlyphMetrics.RightSideBearing
member.summary: Specifies the X offset from the right edge of the black box to the origin of the next glyph when writing horizontally. The value is negative when the right edge of the black box overhangs the layout box.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.GlyphMetrics.AdvanceWidth
member.summary: Specifies the X offset from the origin of the current glyph to the origin of the next glyph when writing horizontally.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.GlyphMetrics.LeftSideBearing
member.summary: Specifies the X offset from the glyph origin to the left edge of the black box. The glyph origin is the current horizontal writing position. A negative value means the black box extends to the left of the origin (often true for lowercase italic 'f').

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.GlyphMetrics
member.summary: The GlyphMetrics structure specifies the metrics of an individual glyph. The units depend on how the metrics are obtained.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FontFeature.Parameter
member.summary: Execution parameter of the feature.
member.remarks: The parameter should be non-zero to enable the feature. Once enabled, a feature can't be disabled again within the same range. Features requiring a selector use this value to indicate the selector index.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FontFeature.NameTag
member.summary: The feature OpenType name identifier.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FontFeature.#ctor(Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Constructor for FontFeature

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FontFeature
member.summary: The FontFeature structure specifies properties used to identify and execute typographic feature in the font.

remarks.para: A non-zero value generally enables the feature execution, while the zero value disables it. A feature requiring a selector uses this value to indicate the selector index.

The OpenType standard provides access to typographic features available in the font by means of a feature tag with the associated parameters. The OpenType feature tag is a 4-byte identifier of the registered name of a feature. For example, the ‘kern’ feature name tag is used to identify the ‘Kerning’ feature in OpenType font. Similarly, the OpenType feature tag for ‘Standard Ligatures’ and ‘Fractions’ is ‘liga’ and ‘frac’ respectively. Since a single run can be associated with more than one typographic features, the Text String API accepts typographic settings for a run as a list of features and are executed in the order they are specified.

The value of the Tag member represents the OpenType name tag of the feature, while the param value represents additional parameter for the execution of the feature referred by the tag member. Both nameTag and param are stored as little endian, the same convention followed by GDI. Most features treat the Param value as a binary value that indicates whether to turn the execution of the feature on or off, with it being off by default in the majority of cases. Some features, however, treat this value as an integral value representing the integer index to the list of alternate results it may produce during the execution; for instance, the feature ‘Stylistic Alternates’ or ‘salt’ uses the param value as an index to the list of alternate substituting glyphs it could produce for a specified glyph.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InlineObjectMetrics.SupportsSideways
member.summary: Flag indicating whether the object is to be placed upright or alongside the text baseline for vertical text.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InlineObjectMetrics.Baseline
member.summary: Distance from the top of the object to the baseline where it is lined up with the adjacent text. If the baseline is at the bottom, baseline simply equals height.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InlineObjectMetrics.Height
member.summary: Height of the inline object as measured from top to bottom.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InlineObjectMetrics.Width
member.summary: Width of the inline object.

member.summary: Constructor for InlineObjectMetrics

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InlineObjectMetrics
member.summary: Properties describing the geometric measurement of an application-defined inline object.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.StrikethroughThickness
member.summary: The suggested strikethrough thickness value of the font face in font design units.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.StrikethroughPosition
member.summary: The strikethrough position value of the font face in font design units. Strikethrough position is the position of strikethrough relative to the English baseline. The value is usually made positive in order to place the strikethrough above the baseline.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.UnderlineThickness
member.summary: The suggested underline thickness value of the font face in font design units.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.UnderlinePosition
member.summary: The underline position value of the font face in font design units. Underline position is the position of underline relative to the English baseline. The value is usually made negative in order to place the underline below the baseline.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.XHeight
member.summary: x-height value of the font face in font design units. x-height is the distance from English baseline to the top of lowercase letter "x", or a similar lowercase character.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.CapHeight
member.summary: Cap height value of the font face in font design units. Cap height is the distance from English baseline to the top of a typical English capital. Capital "H" is often used as a reference character for the purpose of calculating the cap height value.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.LineGap
member.summary: Line gap in font design units. Recommended additional white space to add between lines to improve legibility. The recommended line spacing (baseline-to-baseline distance) is thus the sum of ascent, descent, and lineGap. The line gap is usually positive or zero but can be negative, in which case the recommended line spacing is less than the height of the character alignment box.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.Descent
member.summary: Descent value of the font face in font design units. Descent is the distance from the bottom of font character alignment box to English baseline.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.Ascent
member.summary: Ascent value of the font face in font design units. Ascent is the distance from the top of font character alignment box to English baseline.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.DesignUnitsPerEm
member.summary: The number of font design units per em unit. Font files use their own coordinate system of font design units. A font design unit is the smallest measurable unit in the em square, an imaginary square that is used to size and align glyphs. The concept of em square is used as a reference scale factor when defining font size and device transformation semantics. The size of one em square is also commonly used to compute the paragraph identation value.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.OverhangMetrics
member.summary: Holds information about how much any visible pixels (in DIPs) overshoot each side of the layout or inline objects.
member.remarks: Positive overhangs indicate that the visible area extends outside the layout box or inline object, while negative values mean there is whitespace inside. The returned values are unaffected by rendering transforms or pixel snapping. Additionally, they may not exactly match final target's pixel bounds after applying grid fitting and hinting.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.LineCount
member.summary: Total number of lines.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.MaxBidiReorderingDepth
member.summary: The maximum reordering count of any line of text, used to calculate the most number of hit-testing boxes needed. If the layout has no bidirectional text or no text at all, the minimum level is 1.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.LayoutHeight
member.summary: Initial height given to the layout. Depending on the length of the text, it may be larger or smaller than the text content height.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.LayoutWidth
member.summary: Initial width given to the layout. Depending on whether the text was wrapped or not, it can be either larger or smaller than the text content width.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.Height
member.summary: The height of the formatted text. The height of an empty string is determined by the size of the default font's line height.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.WidthIncludingTrailingWhitespace
member.summary: The width of the formatted text taking into account the trailing whitespace at the end of each line.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.Width
member.summary: The width of the formatted text ignoring trailing whitespace at the end of each line.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.Top
member.summary: Top-most point of formatted text relative to layout box (excluding any glyph overhang).

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.Left
member.summary: Left-most point of formatted text relative to layout box (excluding any glyph overhang).

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.BreakCondition.MayNotBreak
member.summary: There should be no break, unless overruled by a Must condition from the neighboring text span or inline object.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.BreakCondition.CanBreak
member.summary: A break is allowed, unless overruled by the condition of the neighboring text span or inline object, either prohibited by a May Not or forced by a Must.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.BreakCondition.Neutral
member.summary: Whether a break is allowed is determined by the condition of the neighboring text span or inline object.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FontSimulations
member.summary: Specifies algorithmic style simulations to be applied to the font face. Bold and oblique simulations can be combined via bitwise OR operation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FontSimulations.Oblique
member.summary: Algorithmic italicization is performed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FontSimulations.Bold
member.summary: Algorithmic emboldening is performed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FontSimulations.None
member.summary: No simulations are performed.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId
member.summary: The informational string enumeration identifies a string in a font.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.SampleText
member.summary: Sample text. This can be the font name or any other text that the designer thinks is the best example to display the font in.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.PreferredSubfamilyNames
member.summary: Subfamily name preferred by the designer. This name is typically only present if it differs from the GDI-compatible subfamily name.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.PreferredFamilyNames
member.summary: Family name preferred by the designer. This enables font designers to group more than four fonts in a single family without losing compatibility with GDI. This name is typically only present if it differs from the GDI-compatible family name.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.Win32SubfamilyNames
member.summary: GDI-compatible subfamily name.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.Win32FamilyNames
member.summary: GDI-compatible family name. Because GDI allows a maximum of four fonts per family, fonts in the same family may have different GDI-compatible family names (e.g., "Arial", "Arial Narrow", "Arial Black").

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.LicenseInfoUrl
member.summary: URL where additional licensing information can be found.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.LicenseDescription
member.summary: Description of how the font may be legally used, or different example scenarios for licensed use. This field should be written in plain language, not legalese.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.FontVendorUrl
member.summary: URL of font vendor (with protocol, e.g., http://, ftp://). If a unique serial number is embedded in the URL, it can be used to register the font.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.Description
member.summary: Description of the font. Can contain revision information, usage recommendations, history, features, etc.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.DesignerUrl
member.summary: URL of font designer (with protocol, e.g., http://, ftp://).

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.Designer
member.summary: Name of the font designer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.Manufacturer
member.summary: Name of the font manufacturer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.Trademark
member.summary: Trademark information provided by the font.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.VersionStrings
member.summary: String containing a version number.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.CopyrightNotice
member.summary: Copyright notice provided by the font.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.None
member.summary: Unspecified name ID.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.RenderingMode
member.summary: Represents a method of rendering glyphs.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.RenderingMode.Outline
member.summary: Specifies that rendering should bypass the rasterizer and use the outlines directly. This is typically used at very large sizes.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.RenderingMode.CleartypeNaturalSymmetric
member.summary: Specifies ClearType rendering with anti-aliasing in both horizontal and vertical dimensions. This is typically used at larger sizes to makes curves and diagonal lines look smoother, at the expense of some softness.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.RenderingMode.CleartypeNatural
member.summary: Specifies ClearType rendering with anti-aliasing in the horizontal dimension only. This is typically used with small to medium font sizes (up to 16 ppem).

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.RenderingMode.CleartypeGdiNatural
member.summary: Specifies ClearType rendering with the same metrics as text rendering using GDI using a font created with CLEARTYPE_NATURAL_QUALITY. Glyph metrics are closer to their ideal values than with aliased text, but glyphs are still positioned on whole-pixel boundaries.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.RenderingMode.CleartypeGdiClassic
member.summary: Specifies ClearType rendering with the same metrics as aliased text. Glyphs can only be positioned on whole-pixel boundaries.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.RenderingMode.Aliased
member.summary: Specifies that no anti-aliasing is performed. Each pixel is either set to the foreground color of the text or retains the color of the background.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.RenderingMode.Default
member.summary: Specifies that the rendering mode is determined automatically based on the font and size.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.PixelGeometry
member.summary: Represents the internal structure of a device pixel (i.e., the physical arrangement of red, green, and blue color components) that is assumed for purposes of rendering text.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.PixelGeometry.Bgr
member.summary: Each pixel comprises three vertical stripes, with blue on the left, green in the center, and red on the right.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.PixelGeometry.Rgb
member.summary: Each pixel comprises three vertical stripes, with red on the left, green in the center, and blue on the right. This is the most common pixel geometry for LCD monitors.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.PixelGeometry.Flat
member.summary: The red, green, and blue color components of each pixel are assumed to occupy the same point.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.MeasuringMode
member.summary: The measuring method used for text layout.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.MeasuringMode.GdiNatural
member.summary: Text is measured using the same glyph display metrics as text measured by GDI using a font created with CLEARTYPE_NATURAL_QUALITY.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.MeasuringMode.GdiClassic
member.summary: Text is measured using glyph display compatible metrics whose values tuned for the current display resolution.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.MeasuringMode.Natural
member.summary: Text is measured using glyph ideal metrics whose values are independent to the current display resolution.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TrimmingGranularity
member.summary: Text granularity used to trim text overflowing the layout box.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TrimmingGranularity.Word
member.summary: Trimming occurs at word boundary.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TrimmingGranularity.Character
member.summary: Trimming occurs at character cluster boundary.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TrimmingGranularity.None
member.summary: No trimming occurs. Text flows beyond the layout width.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.LineSpacingMethod
member.summary: The method used for line spacing in layout.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.LineSpacingMethod.Uniform
member.summary: Lines are explicitly set to uniform spacing, regardless of contained font sizes. This can be useful to avoid the uneven appearance that can occur from font fallback.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.LineSpacingMethod.Default
member.summary: Line spacing depends solely on the content, growing to accomodate the size of fonts and inline objects.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.WordWrapping
member.summary: Word wrapping in multiline paragraph.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.WordWrapping.NoWrap
member.summary: Words are kept within the same line even when it overflows the layout box. This option is often used with scrolling to reveal overflow text.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.WordWrapping.Wrap
member.summary: Words are broken across lines to avoid text overflowing the layout box.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.ParagraphAlignment
member.summary: Alignment of paragraph text along the flow direction axis relative to the flow's beginning and ending edge of the layout box.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.ParagraphAlignment.Center
member.summary: The center of the paragraph is aligned to the center of the flow of the layout box.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.ParagraphAlignment.Far
member.summary: The last line of paragraph is aligned to the flow's ending edge of the layout box.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.ParagraphAlignment.Near
member.summary: The first line of paragraph is aligned to the flow's beginning edge of the layout box.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TextAlignment
member.summary: Alignment of paragraph text along the reading direction axis relative to the leading and trailing edge of the layout box.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TextAlignment.Center
member.summary: The center of the paragraph text is aligned to the center of the layout box.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TextAlignment.Trailing
member.summary: The trailing edge of the paragraph text is aligned to the layout box's trailing edge.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.TextAlignment.Leading
member.summary: The leading edge of the paragraph text is aligned to the layout box's leading edge.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FlowDirection
member.summary: Direction for how lines of text are placed relative to one another.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.FlowDirection.TopToBottom
member.summary: Text lines are placed from top to bottom.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.ReadingDirection
member.summary: Direction for how reading progresses.

member.summary: Reading progresses from right to left.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.ReadingDirection.LeftToRight
member.summary: Reading progresses from left to right.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.DWriteFactoryType
member.summary: Specifies the type of DirectWrite factory object. DirectWrite factory contains internal state such as font loader registration and cached font data. In most cases it is recommended to use the shared factory object, because it allows multiple components that use DirectWrite to share internal DirectWrite state and reduce memory usage. However, there are cases when it is desirable to reduce the impact of a component, such as a plug-in from an untrusted source, on the rest of the process by sandboxing and isolating it from the rest of the process components. In such cases, it is recommended to use an isolated factory for the sandboxed component.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.DWriteFactoryType.Isolated
member.summary: Objects created from the isolated factory do not interact with internal DirectWrite state from other components.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DirectWrite.DWriteFactoryType.Shared
member.summary: Shared factory allow for re-use of cached font data across multiple in process components. Such factories also take advantage of cross process font caching components for better performance.
