member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTargetProperties.MinLevel
member.summary: A value that specifies the minimum Direct3D feature level required for hardware rendering. If the specified minimum level is not available, the render target uses software rendering if the type member is set to Default; if type is set to to Hardware, render target creation fails. A value of Default indicates that Direct2D should determine whether the Direct3D feature level of the device is adequate. This field is used only when creating HwndRenderTarget and DCRenderTarget objects.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTargetProperties.Usage
member.summary: A value that specifies how the render target is remoted and whether it should be GDI-compatible. Set to None to create a render target that is not compatible with GDI and uses Direct3D command-stream remoting if it is available.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTargetProperties.DpiY
member.summary: The verical DPI of the render target. To use the default DPI, set dpiX and dpiY to 0.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTargetProperties.DpiX
member.summary: The horizontal DPI of the render target. To use the default DPI, set dpiX and dpiY to 0.

member.summary: The pixel format and alpha mode of the render target.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.StrokeStyleProperties.DashOffset
member.summary: A value that specifies an offset in the dash sequence. A positive dash offset value shifts the dash pattern, in units of stroke width, toward the start of the stroked geometry. A negative dash offset value shifts the dash pattern, in units of stroke width, toward the end of the stroked geometry.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.StrokeStyleProperties.DashStyle

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.StrokeStyleProperties.MiterLimit

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.StrokeStyleProperties.LineJoin

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.GradientStop.#ctor(System.Single,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.ColorF)
member.summary: Constructor for the GradientStop value type
member.param: Initializes the position field.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.GradientStop
member.summary:
Contains the position and color of a gradient stop.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_GRADIENT_STOP)

remarks.para: Gradient stops can be specified in any order if they are at different positions. Two stops may share a position. In this case, the first stop specified is treated as the "low" stop (nearer 0.0f) and subsequent stops are treated as "higher" (nearer 1.0f). This behavior is useful if a caller wants an instant transition in the middle of a stop.

Typically, there are at least two points in a collection, although creation with only one stop is permitted. For example, one point is at position 0.0f, another point is at position 1.0f, and additional points are distributed in the [0, 1] range. Where the gradient progression is beyond the range of [0, 1], the stops are stored, but may affect the gradient.
When drawn, the [0, 1] range of positions is mapped to the brush, in a brush-dependent way.

Gradient stops with a position outside the [0, 1] range can not be seen explicitly, but they can still affect the colors produced in the [0, 1] range. For example, a two-stop gradient {{0.0f, Black}, {2.0f, White}} is indistinguishable visually from {{0.0f, Black}, {1.0f, Mid-level gray}}. Also, the colors are clamped before interpolation.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.DCInitializeMode
member.summary:
Specifies how a device context is initialized for GDI rendering when it is retrieved from the render target.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_DC_INITIALIZE_MODE)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.DCInitializeMode.Clear
member.summary: The device context is cleared to transparent black when it is initialized.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.DCInitializeMode.Copy
member.summary: The current contents of the render target are copied to the device context when it is initialized.

member.summary:
Describes whether a window is occluded.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_WINDOW_STATE)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.WindowState.Occluded
member.summary: The window is occluded.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.WindowState.None
member.summary: No window state flags set

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.FillMode
member.summary:
Specifies how the intersecting areas of geometries are combined to form the area of the composite geometry.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_FILL_MODE)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.FillMode.Winding
member.summary: Determines whether a point is in the fill region of the path by drawing a ray from that point to infinity in any direction, and then examining the places where a segment of the shape crosses the ray. Starting with a count of zero, add one each time a segment crosses the ray from left to right and subtract one each time a path segment crosses the ray from right to left, as long as left and right are seen from the perspective of the ray. After counting the crossings, if the result is zero, then the point is outside the path. Otherwise, it is inside the path.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.FillMode.Alternate
member.summary: Determines whether a point is in the fill region by drawing a ray from that point to infinity in any direction, and then counting the number of path segments within the given shape that the ray crosses. If this number is odd, the point is in the fill region; if even, the point is outside the fill region.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.TextAntialiasMode
member.summary:
Describes the antialiasing mode used for drawing text.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_TEXT_ANTIALIAS_MODE)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.TextAntialiasMode.Aliased
member.summary: Do not use antialiasing.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.TextAntialiasMode.Grayscale
member.summary: Render text using gray-scale antialiasing.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.TextAntialiasMode.ClearType
member.summary: Render text using ClearType antialiasing.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.TextAntialiasMode.Default
member.summary: Render text using the current system setting.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.SweepDirection
member.summary:
Defines the direction that an elliptical arc is drawn.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_SWEEP_DIRECTION)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.SweepDirection.Clockwise
member.summary: Arcs are drawn in a clockwise (positive-angle) direction.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.SweepDirection.CounterClockwise
member.summary: Arcs are drawn in a counterclockwise (negative-angle) direction.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.CompatibleRenderTargetOptions
member.summary:
Specifies additional features supportable by a compatible render target when it is created. This enumeration allows a bitwise combination of its member values.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_COMPATIBLE_RENDER_TARGET_OPTIONS)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.CompatibleRenderTargetOptions.GdiCompatible
member.summary: The render target supports interoperability with the Windows Graphics Device Interface (GDI).

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.CompatibleRenderTargetOptions.None
member.summary: The render target supports no additional features.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTargetType
member.summary:
Describes whether a render target uses hardware or software rendering, or if Direct2D should select the rendering mode.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_RENDER_TARGET_TYPE)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTargetType.Hardware
member.summary: The render target uses hardware rendering only.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTargetType.Software
member.summary: The render target uses software rendering only.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTargetType.Default
member.summary: The render target uses hardware rendering, if available; otherwise, it uses software rendering.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTargetUsage
member.summary:
Describes how a render target is remoted and whether it should be GDI-compatible. This enumeration allows a bitwise combination of its member values.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_RENDER_TARGET_USAGE)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTargetUsage.GdiCompatible
member.summary: The render target can be used efficiently with GDI.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTargetUsage.ForceBitmapRemoting
member.summary: The render target renders content locally and sends it to the terminal services client as a bitmap.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.RenderTargetUsage.None
member.summary: The render target attempts to use Direct3D command-stream remoting and uses bitmap remoting if stream remoting fails. The render target is not GDI-compatible.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.PresentOptions
member.summary:
Describes how a render target behaves when it presents its content. This enumeration allows a bitwise combination of its member values.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_PRESENT_OPTIONS)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.PresentOptions.Immediately
member.summary: The render target does not wait until the display refreshes to present.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.PresentOptions.RetainContents
member.summary: The render target does not discard the frame upon presenting.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.PresentOptions.None
member.summary: The render target waits until the display refreshes to present and discards the frame upon presenting.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.LineJoin
member.summary:
Describes the shape that joins two lines or segments.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_LINE_JOIN)
member.remarks: A miter limit affects how sharp miter joins are allowed to be. If the line join style MiterOrBevel, then the join will be mitered with regular angular vertices if it doesn't extend beyond the miter limit; otherwise, the line join will be beveled.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.LineJoin.MiterOrBevel
member.summary: Regular angular vertices unless the join would extend beyond the miter limit; otherwise, beveled vertices.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.LineJoin.Round
member.summary: Rounded vertices.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.LineJoin.Bevel
member.summary: Beveled vertices.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.LineJoin.Miter
member.summary: Regular angular vertices.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.LayerOptions
member.summary:
Specified options that can be applied when a layer resource is applied to create a layer.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_LAYER_OPTIONS)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.LayerOptions.InitializeForClearType
member.summary: The layer will render correctly for ClearType text. If the render target was set to ClearType previously, the layer will continue to render ClearType. If the render target was set to ClearType and this option is not specified, the render target will be set to render gray-scale until the layer is popped. The caller can override this default by calling SetTextAntialiasMode while within the layer. This flag is slightly slower than the default.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.LayerOptions.None
member.summary: The text in this layer does not use ClearType antialiasing.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.CapStyle
member.summary:
Enum which descibes the drawing of the ends of a line.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_CAP_STYLE)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.CapStyle.Triangle
member.summary: An isosceles right triangle whose hypotenuse is equal in length to the thickness of the line.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.CapStyle.Round
member.summary: A semicircle that has a diameter equal to the line thickness.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.CapStyle.Square
member.summary: Half of a square that has a length equal to the line thickness.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.CapStyle.Flat
member.summary: A cap that does not extend past the last point of the line. Comparable to cap used for objects other than lines.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.PathSegment
member.summary:
Indicates whether the given segment should be stroked, or, if the join between this segment and the previous one should be smooth.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_PATH_SEGMENT)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.PathSegment.ForceRoundLineJoin
member.summary: The segment is always joined with the one preceding it using a round line join, regardless of which LineJoin enumeration is specified by the StrokeStyle class. If this segment is the first segment and the figure is closed, a round line join is used to connect the closing segment with the first segment. If the figure is not closed, this setting has no effect on the first segment of the figure.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.PathSegment.ForceUnstroked
member.summary: The segment is not stroked.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.PathSegment.None
member.summary: The segment is joined as specified by the StrokeStyle class, and it is stroked.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.GeometryRelation.Overlap
member.summary: The two geometries overlap but neither completely contains the other.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.GeometryRelation.Contains
member.summary: The object entirely contains the passed in geometry.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.GeometryRelation.IsContained
member.summary: The passed in geometry is entirely contained by the object.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.GeometryRelation.Disjoint
member.summary: The two geometries do not intersect at all.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.GeometryRelation.Unknown
member.summary: The relation between the geometries couldn't be determined. This value is never returned by any D2D method.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.FigureEnd
member.summary:
Indicates whether the figure is open or closed on its end point.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_FIGURE_END)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.FigureEnd.Closed
member.summary: The figure is closed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.FigureEnd.Open
member.summary: The figure is open.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.FigureBegin
member.summary:
Indicates whether the given figure is filled or hollow.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_FIGURE_BEGIN)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.FigureBegin.Hollow
member.summary: The figure is hollow.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.FigureBegin.Filled
member.summary: The figure is filled.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.D2DFactoryType
member.summary:
Specifies the threading model of the created factory and all of its derived resources.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_FACTORY_TYPE)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.D2DFactoryType.MultiThreaded
member.summary: The resulting factory may be invoked from multiple threads. Returned resources use interlocked reference counting and their state is protected.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.D2DFactoryType.SingleThreaded
member.summary: The resulting factory and derived resources may only be invoked serially. Reference counts on resources are interlocked, however, resource and render target state is not protected from multi-threaded access.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.ExtendMode
member.summary:
Specifies how a brush paints areas outside of its normal content area.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_EXTEND_MODE)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.ExtendMode.Mirror
member.summary: The same as wrap, except that alternate tiles of the brush's content are flipped. (The brush's normal content is drawn untransformed).

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.ExtendMode.Wrap
member.summary: Repeat the brush's content.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.ExtendMode.Clamp
member.summary: Repeat the edge pixels of the brush's content for all regions outside the normal content area.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.AlphaMode
member.summary:
Specifies how the alpha value of a bitmap or render target should be treated.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_ALPHA_MODE)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.AlphaMode.Ignore
member.summary: Ignore any alpha channel information.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.AlphaMode.Straight
member.summary: The alpha value has not been premultiplied; ie. opacity is in the 'A' component only.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.AlphaMode.Premultiplied
member.summary: The alpha value has been premultiplied. Each color is first scaled by the alpha value. If the multiplied format is greater than the alpha channel, the standard Source Over blending math creates an additive blend.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.AlphaMode.Unknown
member.summary: Alpha mode should be determined implicitly. Some target surfaces do not supply or imply this information in which case alpha must be specified.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.AntialiasMode
member.summary:
Describes how non-text primitives are rendered.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_ANTIALIAS_MODE)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.AntialiasMode.Aliased
member.summary: Objects are aliased in most cases. Objects are antialiased only when they are drawn to a render target created by the CreateDxgiSurfaceRenderTarget method and Direct3D multisampling has been enabled on the backing DirectX Graphics Infrastructure (DXGI) surface.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.AntialiasMode.PerPrimitive
member.summary: Edges are antialiased using the Direct2D per-primitive method of high-quality antialiasing.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.DrawTextOptions
member.summary:
Specifies whether text snapping is suppressed or clipping to the layout rectangle is enabled. This enumeration allows a bitwise combination of its member values.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_DRAW_TEXT_OPTIONS)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.DrawTextOptions.Clip
member.summary: Text is clipped to the layout rectangle.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.DrawTextOptions.NoSnap
member.summary: Text is not vertically snapped to pixel boundaries. This setting is recommended for text that is being animated.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.DrawTextOptions.None
member.summary: Text is vertically snapped to pixel boundaries and is not clipped to the layout rectangle.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.DebugLevel
member.summary:
Indicates the type of information that Direct2D sends to the debug layer.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_DEBUG_LEVEL)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.DebugLevel.Information
member.summary: Direct2D sends error messages, warnings, and additional diagnostic information to the debug layer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.DebugLevel.Warning
member.summary: Direct2D sends error messages and warnings to the debug layer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.DebugLevel.Error
member.summary: Direct2D sends error messages to the debug layer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.DebugLevel.None
member.summary: Direct2D does not produce any debugging output.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.DashStyle
member.summary:
Describes the sequence of dashes and gaps in a stroke.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_DASH_STYLE)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.DashStyle.Custom
member.summary: The dash pattern is specified by an array of floating-point values.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.DashStyle.DashDotDot
member.summary:
A dash, followed by a gap, followed by a dot, followed by another gap, followed by another dot, followed by another gap.
The equivalent dash array is {2, 2, 0, 2, 0, 2}.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.DashStyle.DashDot
member.summary:
A dash, followed by a gap, followed by a dot, followed by another gap.
The equivalent dash array is {2, 2, 0, 2}.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.DashStyle.Dot
member.summary:
A dot followed by a longer gap.
The equivalent dash array is {0, 2}.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.DashStyle.Dash
member.summary:
A dash followed by a gap of equal length. The dash and the gap are each twice as long as the stroke thickness.
The equivalent dash array is {2, 2}.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.DashStyle.Solid
member.summary: A solid line with no breaks.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.CombineMode
member.summary:
This enumeration describes the type of combine operation to be performed.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_COMBINE_MODE)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.CombineMode.Exclude
member.summary: The second region is excluded from the first. Given two geometries, A and B, the area of geometry B is removed from the area of geometry A, producing a region that is A-B.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.CombineMode.Xor
member.summary: The two regions are combined by taking the area that exists in the first region but not the second and the area that exists in the second region but not the first. Given two geometries, A and B, the new region consists of (A-B) + (B-A).

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.CombineMode.Intersect
member.summary: The two regions are combined by taking their intersection. The new area consists of the overlapping region between the two geometries.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.CombineMode.Union
member.summary: The two regions are combined by taking the union of both. Given two geometries, A and B, the resulting geometry is geometry A + geometry B.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.OpacityMaskContent
member.summary:
Describes whether an opacity mask contains graphics or text. Direct2D uses this information to determine which gamma space to use when blending the opacity mask.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_OPACITY_MASK_CONTENT)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.OpacityMaskContent.TextGdiCompatible
member.summary: The opacity mask contains text rendered using the GDI-compatible rendering mode. The opacity mask is blended using the gamma for GDI rendering.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.OpacityMaskContent.TextNatural
member.summary: The opacity mask contains non-GDI text. The gamma space used for blending is obtained from the render target's text rendering parameters (RenderTarget.TextRenderingParams)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.OpacityMaskContent.Graphics
member.summary: The opacity mask contains graphics. The opacity mask is blended in the gamma 2.2 color space.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.Gamma
member.summary:
This determines what gamma is used for interpolation/blending.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_GAMMA)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.Gamma.Gamma_10
member.summary: Interpolation and blending are performed in the linear-gamma color space.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.Gamma.Gamma_22
member.summary: Interpolation and blending are performed in the standard RGB (sRGB) standard gamma.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.BitmapInterpolationMode
member.summary:
Specifies the algorithm that is used when images are scaled or rotated.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D2D1_BITMAP_INTERPOLATION_MODE)
member.remarks: To stretch an image, each pixel in the original image must be mapped to a group of pixels in the larger image. To shrink an image, groups of pixels in the original image must be mapped to single pixels in the smaller image. The effectiveness of the algorithms that perform these mappings determines the quality of a scaled image. Algorithms that produce higher-quality scaled images tend to require more processing time. NearestNeighbor provides faster but lower-quality interpolation, while Linear provides higher-quality interpolation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.BitmapInterpolationMode.Linear
member.summary: Interpolate a color from the four bitmap pixels that are the nearest to the rendering pixel.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.BitmapInterpolationMode.NearestNeighbor
member.summary: Use the exact color of the nearest bitmap pixel to the current rendering pixel.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct2D1.GeometrySimplificationOption
member.summary:
Specifies how a geometry is simplified to a SimplifiedGeometrySink.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.StreamOutputDeclarationEntry.StartComponent

(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_SO_DECLARATION_ENTRY.StartComponent)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.SamplerDescription.MaxLOD
member.summary:
Upper end of the mipmap range to clamp access to, where 0 is the largest and most detailed mipmap level and any level higher than that is less detailed. This value must be greater than or equal to MinLOD. To have no upper limit on LOD set this to a large value such as D3D10_FLOAT32_MAX.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_SAMPLER_DESC.MaxLOD)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.SamplerDescription.MinLOD
member.summary:
Lower end of the mipmap range to clamp access to, where 0 is the largest and most detailed mipmap level and any level higher than that is less detailed.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_SAMPLER_DESC.MinLOD)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.SamplerDescription.BorderColor
member.summary:
Border color to use if Border is specified for AddressU, AddressV, or AddressW. Range must be between 0.0 and 1.0 inclusive.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_SAMPLER_DESC.BorderColor)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.SamplerDescription.ComparisonFunction
member.summary:
A function that compares sampled data against existing sampled data. The function options are listed in ComparisonFunction.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_SAMPLER_DESC.ComparisonFunc)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.SamplerDescription.MaxAnisotropy
member.summary:
Clamping value used if Anisotropic or ComparisonAnisotropic is specified in Filter. Valid values are between 1 and 16.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_SAMPLER_DESC.MaxAnisotropy)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.SamplerDescription.MipLODBias
member.summary:
Offset from the calculated mipmap level. For example, if Direct3D calculates that a texture should be sampled at mipmap level 3 and MipLODBias is 2, then the texture will be sampled at mipmap level 5.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_SAMPLER_DESC.MipLODBias)

member.summary:
Method to use for resolving a w texture coordinate that is outside the 0 to 1 range.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_SAMPLER_DESC.AddressW)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.RasterizerDescription.AntialiasedLineEnable
member.summary:
Enable or disables line antialiasing. Note that this option only applies when alpha blending is enabled, you are drawing lines, and the MultisampleEnable member is FALSE. The default value is FALSE.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_RASTERIZER_DESC.AntialiasedLineEnable)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.RasterizerDescription.MultisampleEnable
member.summary:
Enables or disables multisample antialiasing. The default value is FALSE.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_RASTERIZER_DESC.MultisampleEnable)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.RasterizerDescription.ScissorEnable
member.summary:
Enable or disables scissor-rectangle culling. All pixels outside an active scissor rectangle are culled. The default value is FALSE. For more information, see Set the Scissor Rectangle.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_RASTERIZER_DESC.ScissorEnable)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.RasterizerDescription.DepthClipEnable
member.summary:
Enables or disables clipping based on distance. The default value is TRUE.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_RASTERIZER_DESC.DepthClipEnable)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.RasterizerDescription.SlopeScaledDepthBias
member.summary:
Specifies a scalar on a given pixel's slope. The default value is 0.0f. For more information, see Depth Bias.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_RASTERIZER_DESC.SlopeScaledDepthBias)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.RasterizerDescription.DepthBiasClamp
member.summary:
Specifies the maximum depth bias of a pixel. The default value is 0.0f. For more information, see Depth Bias.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_RASTERIZER_DESC.DepthBiasClamp)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.RasterizerDescription.DepthBias
member.summary:
Specifies the depth value added to a given pixel. The default value is 0. For more information, see Depth Bias.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_RASTERIZER_DESC.DepthBias)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.RasterizerDescription.FrontCounterClockwise
member.summary:
Determines if a triangle is front-facing or back-facing. If this parameter is TRUE, then a triangle is considered front-facing if its vertices are counter-clockwise on the render target, and considered back-facing if they are clockwise. If this parameter is FALSE, then the opposite is true. The default value is FALSE.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_RASTERIZER_DESC.FrontCounterClockwise)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.RasterizerDescription.CullMode
member.summary:
A member of the CullMode enumerated type that indicates whether triangles facing the specified direction are drawn. The default value is Back.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_RASTERIZER_DESC.CullMode)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.RasterizerDescription.FillMode
member.summary:
A member of the FillMode enumerated type that determines the fill mode to use when rendering. The default value is Solid.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_RASTERIZER_DESC.FillMode)

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.RasterizerDescription
member.summary:
Describes the rasterizer state.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_RASTERIZER_DESC)

member.summary:
Miscellaneous flags (see ).
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_DESC.MiscFlags)

member.summary:
Type of query.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_DESC.D3DQuery)

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.QueryDescription
member.summary:
Describes a query.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_DESC)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.QueryDataTimestampDisjoint.Disjoint
member.summary:
If this is TRUE, something occurred in between the query's Asynchronous.Begin and Asynchronous.End calls that caused the timestamp counter to become discontinuous or disjoint, such as unplugging the AC chord on a laptop, overheating, or throttling up/down due to laptop savings events. The timestamp returned by Asynchronous.GetData for a timestamp query is only reliable if Disjoint is FALSE.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_DATA_TIMESTAMP_DISJOINT.Disjoint)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.QueryDataTimestampDisjoint.Frequency
member.summary:
How frequently the GPU counter increments in Hz.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_DATA_TIMESTAMP_DISJOINT.Frequency)

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.QueryDataTimestampDisjoint
member.summary:
Query information about the reliability of a timestamp query.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_DATA_TIMESTAMP_DISJOINT)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.QueryDataStreamOuputStatistics.PrimitivesStorageNeeded
member.summary:
Number of primitives that would have been written to the stream-output buffers if there had been enough space for them all.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_DATA_SO_STATISTICS.PrimitivesStorageNeeded)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.QueryDataStreamOuputStatistics.NumPrimitivesWritten
member.summary:
Number of primitives (that is, points, lines, and triangles) written to the stream-output buffers.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_DATA_SO_STATISTICS.NumPrimitivesWritten)

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.QueryDataStreamOuputStatistics
member.summary:
Query information about the amount of data streamed out to the stream-output buffers in between Asynchronous.Begin and Asynchronous.End.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_DATA_SO_STATISTICS)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.QueryDataPipelineStatistics.PixelShaderInvocations
member.summary:
Number of times a pixel shader was invoked.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_DATA_PIPELINE_STATISTICS.PSInvocations)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.QueryDataPipelineStatistics.CPrimitives
member.summary:
Number of primitives that were rendered. This may be larger or smaller than CInvocations because after a primitive is clipped sometimes it is either broken up into more than one primitive or completely culled.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_DATA_PIPELINE_STATISTICS.CPrimitives)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.QueryDataPipelineStatistics.CInvocations
member.summary:
Number of primitives that were sent to the rasterizer. When the rasterizer is disabled, this will not increment.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_DATA_PIPELINE_STATISTICS.CInvocations)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.QueryDataPipelineStatistics.GeometryShaderPrimitives
member.summary:
Number of primitives output by a geometry shader.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_DATA_PIPELINE_STATISTICS.GSPrimitives)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.QueryDataPipelineStatistics.GeometryShaderInvocations
member.summary:
Number of times a geometry shader was invoked. When the geometry shader is set to NULL, this statistic may or may not increment depending on the hardware manufacturer.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_DATA_PIPELINE_STATISTICS.GSInvocations)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.QueryDataPipelineStatistics.VertexShaderInvocations
member.summary:
Number of times a vertex shader was invoked. Direct3D invokes the vertex shader once per vertex.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_DATA_PIPELINE_STATISTICS.VSInvocations)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.QueryDataPipelineStatistics.InputAssemblerPrimitives
member.summary:
Number of primitives read by the input assembler. This number can be different depending on the primitive topology used. For example, a triangle strip with 6 vertices will produce 4 triangles, however a triangle list with 6 vertices will produce 2 triangles.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_DATA_PIPELINE_STATISTICS.IAPrimitives)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.QueryDataPipelineStatistics.InputAssemblerVertices
member.summary:
Number of vertices read by input assembler.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_DATA_PIPELINE_STATISTICS.IAVertices)

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.QueryDataPipelineStatistics
member.summary:
Query information about graphics-pipeline activity in between calls to Asynchronous.Begin and Asynchronous.End.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_DATA_PIPELINE_STATISTICS)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.PassShaderDescription.ShaderIndex
member.summary:
A zero-based array index; otherwise 0.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_PASS_SHADER_DESC.ShaderIndex)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.PassShaderDescription.ShaderVariable
member.summary:
The variable that the shader came from. If it is an inline shader assignment, the returned interface will be an anonymous shader variable, which is not retrievable any other way. Its name in the variable description will be "$Anonymous". If there is no assignment of this type in the pass block, this will point to a shader variable that returns false when IsValid is called.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_PASS_SHADER_DESC.pShaderVariable)

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.PassShaderDescription
member.summary:
Describes an effect variable that contains a shader.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_PASS_SHADER_DESC)

member.name: P:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.PassDescription.BlendFactor
member.summary:
The per-component blend factors (RGBA) for the blend state (see Configuring Blending Functionality (Direct3D 10)).
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_PASS_DESC.BlendFactor)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.MappedTexture3D.DepthPitch

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.MappedTexture3D.RowPitch
member.summary:
The pitch, or width, or physical size (in bytes) of one row of an uncompressed texture. Since a block-compressed texture is encoded in 4x4 blocks, the RowPitch for a compressed texture is the number of bytes in a block of 4x4 texels. See virtual size vs physical size for more information on block compression.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_MAPPED_TEXTURE3D.RowPitch)

(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_MAPPED_TEXTURE3D)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.MappedTexture2D.RowPitch
member.summary:
The pitch, or width, or physical size (in bytes), of one row of an uncompressed texture. A block-compressed texture is encoded in 4x4 blocks (see virtual size vs physical size) ; therefore, RowPitch is the number of bytes in a block of 4x4 texels.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_MAPPED_TEXTURE2D.RowPitch)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.InputElementDescription.InstanceDataStepRate
member.summary:
The number of instances to draw before stepping one unit forward in a vertex buffer filled with instance data. Can be any unsigned integer value (0 means do not step) when the slot class is D3D10_INPUT_PER_INSTANCE_DATA; must be 0 when the slot class is PerVertexData.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_INPUT_ELEMENT_DESC.InstanceDataStepRate)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.InputElementDescription.InputSlotClass

(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_INPUT_ELEMENT_DESC.InputSlotClass)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.InputElementDescription.AlignedByteOffset
member.summary:
Optional. Offset (in bytes) between each element. Use D3D10_APPEND_ALIGNED_ELEMENT for convenience to define the current element directly after the previous one, including any packing if necessary.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_INPUT_ELEMENT_DESC.AlignedByteOffset)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.InputElementDescription.InputSlot
member.summary:

(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_INPUT_ELEMENT_DESC.InputSlot)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.InputElementDescription.SemanticIndex
member.summary:
The semantic index for the element. A semantic index modifies a semantic, with an integer index number. A semantic index is only needed in a case where there is more than one element with the same semantic. For example, a 4x4 matrix would have four components each with the semantic name matrix, however each of the four component would have different semantic indices (0, 1, 2, and 3).
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_INPUT_ELEMENT_DESC.SemanticIndex)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.InputElementDescription.SemanticName

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.DepthStencilDescription.BackFace
member.summary:
A DepthStencilOperationDescription structure that identifies how to use the results of the depth test and the stencil test for pixels whose surface normal is facing away from the camera.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_DEPTH_STENCIL_DESC.BackFace)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.DepthStencilDescription.FrontFace
member.summary:
A DepthStencilOperationDescription structure that identifies how to use the results of the depth test and the stencil test for pixels whose surface normal is facing toward the camera.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_DEPTH_STENCIL_DESC.FrontFace)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.DepthStencilDescription.StencilWriteMask
member.summary:
A value that identifies a portion of the depth-stencil buffer for writing stencil data. The default value is Default.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_DEPTH_STENCIL_DESC.StencilWriteMask)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.DepthStencilDescription.StencilReadMask
member.summary:
A value that identifies a portion of the depth-stencil buffer for reading stencil data. The default value is Default.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_DEPTH_STENCIL_DESC.StencilReadMask)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.DepthStencilDescription.StencilEnable
member.summary:
A Boolean value that enables stencil testing. The default value is FALSE.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_DEPTH_STENCIL_DESC.StencilEnable)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.DepthStencilDescription.DepthFunction
member.summary:
A member of the ComparisonFunction enumerated type that defines how depth data is compared against existing depth data. The default value is Less
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_DEPTH_STENCIL_DESC.DepthFunc)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.DepthStencilDescription.DepthWriteMask
member.summary:
A member of the DepthWriteMask enumerated type that identifies a portion of the depth-stencil buffer that can be modified by depth data. The default value is DepthWriteMask_ALL.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_DEPTH_STENCIL_DESC.DepthWriteMask)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.DepthStencilDescription.DepthEnable
member.summary:
A Boolean value that enables depth testing. The default value is TRUE.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_DEPTH_STENCIL_DESC.DepthEnable)

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.DepthStencilDescription
member.summary:
Describes depth-stencil state.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_DEPTH_STENCIL_DESC)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.CounterInformation.NumDetectableParallelUnits
member.summary:
Number of detectable parallel units that the counter is able to discern. Values are 1 ~ 4. Use NumDetectableParallelUnits to interpret the values of the VERTEX_PROCESSING, GEOMETRY_PROCESSING, PIXEL_PROCESSING, and OTHER_GPU_PROCESSING counters. See Asynchronous.GetData for an equation.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_COUNTER_INFO.NumDetectableParallelUnits)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.CounterInformation.NumSimultaneousCounters
member.summary:
Number of counters that can be simultaneously supported.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_COUNTER_INFO.NumSimultaneousCounters)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.CounterInformation.LastDeviceDependentCounter
member.summary:
Largest device-dependent counter ID that the device supports. If none are supported, this value will be 0. Otherwise it will be greater than or equal to DeviceDependent0. See Counter.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_COUNTER_INFO.LastDeviceDependentCounter)

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.CounterInformation
member.summary:
Information about the video card's performance counter capabilities.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_COUNTER_INFO)

member.summary:

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.DepthStencilOperationDescription.StencilPassOperation
member.summary:
A member of the StencilOperation enumerated type that describes the stencil operation to perform when stencil testing and depth testing both pass. The default value is StencilOperation_KEEP.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_DEPTH_STENCILOP_DESC.StencilPassOp)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.DepthStencilOperationDescription.StencilDepthFailOperation
member.summary:
A member of the StencilOperation enumerated type that describes the stencil operation to perform when stencil testing passes and depth testing fails. The default value is StencilOperation_KEEP.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_DEPTH_STENCILOP_DESC.StencilDepthFailOp)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.DepthStencilOperationDescription.StencilFailOperation
member.summary:
A member of the StencilOperation enumerated type that describes the stencil operation to perform when stencil testing fails. The default value is StencilOperation_KEEP.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_DEPTH_STENCILOP_DESC.StencilFailOp)

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.DepthStencilOperationDescription
member.summary:

(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_DEPTH_STENCILOP_DESC)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.StreamOuputOverflowPredicate
member.summary:
Determines whether or not any of the streaming output buffers overflowed in between Asynchronous.Begin and Asynchronous.End. Asynchronous.GetData returns a BOOL - TRUE meaning there was an overflow, FALSE meaning there was not an overflow. If streaming output writes to multiple buffers, and one of the buffers overflows, then it will stop writing to all the output buffers. When an overflow is detected by Direct3D it is prevented from happening - no memory is corrupted. This predication may be used in conjunction with an SO_STATISTICS query so that when an overflow occurs the SO_STATISTIC query will let the application know how much memory was needed to prevent an overflow.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_SO_OVERFLOW_PREDICATE)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.StreamOuputStatistics
member.summary:
Get streaming output statistics, such as the number of primitives streamed out in between Asynchronous.Begin and Asynchronous.End. Asynchronous.GetData will return a QueryDataStreamOuputStatistics structure.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_SO_STATISTICS)

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D10.MessageCategory
member.summary:
Categories of debug messages. This will identify the category of a message when retrieving a message with InfoQueue.GetMessage and when adding a message with InfoQueue.AddMessage. When creating an info queue filter, these values can be used to allow or deny any categories of messages to pass through the storage and retrieval filters.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_MESSAGE_CATEGORY)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.SamplerDescription.MaxLOD
member.summary:
Upper end of the mipmap range to clamp access to, where 0 is the largest and most detailed mipmap level and any level higher than that is less detailed. This value must be greater than or equal to MinLOD. To have no upper limit on LOD set this to a large value such as D3D11_FLOAT32_MAX.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_SAMPLER_DESC.MaxLOD)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.SamplerDescription.MinLOD
member.summary:
Lower end of the mipmap range to clamp access to, where 0 is the largest and most detailed mipmap level and any level higher than that is less detailed.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_SAMPLER_DESC.MinLOD)

member.summary:

(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_SAMPLER_DESC.BorderColor)

offset from the calculated mipmap level. For example, if Direct3D calculates that a texture should be sampled at mipmap level 3 and MipLODBias is 2, then the texture will be sampled at mipmap level 5.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_SAMPLER_DESC.MipLODBias)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.QueryDataTimestampDisjoint.Disjoint
member.summary:
If this is TRUE, something occurred in between the query's DeviceContext.Begin and DeviceContext.End calls that caused the timestamp counter to become discontinuous or disjoint, such as unplugging the AC chord on a laptop, overheating, or throttling up/down due to laptop savings events. The timestamp returned by DeviceContext.GetData for a timestamp query is only reliable if Disjoint is FALSE.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_QUERY_DATA_TIMESTAMP_DISJOINT.Disjoint)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.QueryDataTimestampDisjoint.Frequency
member.summary:

(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_QUERY_DATA_TIMESTAMP_DISJOINT.Frequency)

Number of primitives that were rendered. This may be larger or smaller than CInvocations because after a primitive is clipped sometimes it is either broken up into more than one primitive or completely culled.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_QUERY_DATA_PIPELINE_STATISTICS.CPrimitives)

member.summary:

member.summary:

member.summary:

(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_QUERY_DATA_PIPELINE_STATISTICS.IAPrimitives)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.InputElementDescription.SemanticIndex
member.summary:
The semantic index for the element. A semantic index modifies a semantic, with an integer index number. A semantic index is only needed in a case where there is more than one element with the same semantic. For example, a 4x4 matrix would have four components each with the semantic name matrix, however each of the four component would have different semantic indices (0, 1, 2, and 3).
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_INPUT_ELEMENT_DESC.SemanticIndex)

member.summary:
The HLSL semantic associated with this element in a shader input-signature.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_INPUT_ELEMENT_DESC.SemanticName)

(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_INPUT_ELEMENT_DESC)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.FeatureDataThreading.DriverCommandLists
member.summary:
TRUE means command lists are supported by the current driver; FALSE means that the API will emulate deferred contexts and command lists with software.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_FEATURE_DATA_THREADING.DriverCommandLists)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.FeatureDataThreading.DriverConcurrentCreates
member.summary:
TRUE means resources can be created concurrently on multiple threads while drawing; FALSE means that the presence of coarse synchronization will prevent concurrency.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_FEATURE_DATA_THREADING.DriverConcurrentCreates)

(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_FEATURE_DATA_THREADING)

members.member:
Number of detectable parallel units that the counter is able to discern. Values are 1 ~ 4. Use NumDetectableParallelUnits to interpret the values of the VERTEX_PROCESSING, GEOMETRY_PROCESSING, PIXEL_PROCESSING, and OTHER_GPU_PROCESSING counters.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_COUNTER_INFO.NumDetectableParallelUnits);

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.Usage
member.summary:
Identifies expected resource use during rendering. The usage directly reflects whether a resource is accessible by the CPU and/or the GPU.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_USAGE)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Staging
member.summary:
A resource that supports data transfer (copy) from the GPU to the CPU.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_USAGE_STAGING)

A resource that supports data transfer (copy) from the GPU to the CPU.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_USAGE_STAGING)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Dynamic
member.summary:
A resource that is accessible by both the GPU (read only) and the CPU (write only). A dynamic resource is a good choice for a resource that will be updated by the CPU at least once per frame. There are two ways to update a dynamic resource: if your data is laid exactly the way the resource stores it, use DeviceContext.UpdateSubresource, otherwise, use a Map method.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_USAGE_DYNAMIC)

A resource that is accessible by both the GPU and the CPU (write only). A dynamic resource is a good choice for a resource that will be updated by the CPU at least once per frame. If your data is laid exactly the way the resource stores it, use Device.UpdateSubresource; otherwise, use a Map method. You can write to a dynamic resource on the GPU using Device.CopyResource or Device.CopySubresourceRegion.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_USAGE_DYNAMIC)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Immutable
member.summary:
A resource that can only be read by the GPU. It cannot be written by the GPU, and cannot be accessed at all by the CPU. This type of resource must be initialized when it is created, since it cannot be changed after creation.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_USAGE_IMMUTABLE)

A resource that can only be read by the GPU. It cannot be written by the GPU, and cannot be accessed at all by the CPU. This type of resource must be initialized when it is created, since it cannot be changed after creation.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_USAGE_IMMUTABLE)

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.UnorderedAccessViewDimension
member.summary:

(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_UAV_DIMENSION)

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.TextureAddressMode
member.summary:
Identify a technique for resolving texture coordinates that are outside of the boundaries of a texture.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_TEXTURE_ADDRESS_MODE)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.MirrorOnce
member.summary:
Similar to Mirror and Clamp. Takes the absolute value of the texture coordinate (thus, mirroring around 0), and then clamps to the maximum value.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_TEXTURE_ADDRESS_MIRROR_ONCE)

Similar to Mirror and Clamp. Takes the absolute value of the texture coordinate (thus, mirroring around 0), and then clamps to the maximum value.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_TEXTURE_ADDRESS_MIRROR_ONCE)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Border
member.summary:
Texture coordinates outside the range [0.0, 1.0] are set to the border color specified in SamplerDescription or HLSL code.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_TEXTURE_ADDRESS_BORDER)

Texture coordinates outside the range [0.0, 1.0] are set to the border color specified in SamplerDescription or HLSL code.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_TEXTURE_ADDRESS_BORDER)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Clamp
member.summary:
Texture coordinates outside the range [0.0, 1.0] are set to the texture color at 0.0 or 1.0, respectively.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_TEXTURE_ADDRESS_CLAMP)

Texture coordinates outside the range [0.0, 1.0] are set to the texture color at 0.0 or 1.0, respectively.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_TEXTURE_ADDRESS_CLAMP)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Mirror
member.summary:
Flip the texture at every (u,v) integer junction. For u values between 0 and 1, for example, the texture is addressed normally; between 1 and 2, the texture is flipped (mirrored); between 2 and 3, the texture is normal again; and so on.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_TEXTURE_ADDRESS_MIRROR)

Flip the texture at every integer junction. For u values between 0 and 1, for example, the texture is addressed normally; between 1 and 2, the texture is flipped (mirrored); between 2 and 3, the texture is normal again; and so on.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_TEXTURE_ADDRESS_MIRROR)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Wrap
member.summary:
Tile the texture at every (u,v) integer junction. For example, for u values between 0 and 3, the texture is repeated three times.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_TEXTURE_ADDRESS_WRAP)

Tile the texture at every integer junction. For example, for u values between 0 and 3, the texture is repeated three times.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_TEXTURE_ADDRESS_WRAP)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.StreamOutputOverflowPredicate
member.summary:
Determines whether or not any of the streaming output buffers overflowed in between DeviceContext.Begin and DeviceContext.End. DeviceContext.GetData returns a BOOL - TRUE meaning there was an overflow, FALSE meaning there was not an overflow. If streaming output writes to multiple buffers, and one of the buffers overflows, then it will stop writing to all the output buffers. When an overflow is detected by Direct3D it is prevented from happening - no memory is corrupted. This predication may be used in conjunction with an SO_STATISTICS query so that when an overflow occurs the SO_STATISTIC query will let the application know how much memory was needed to prevent an overflow.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_QUERY_SO_OVERFLOW_PREDICATE)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.StreamOutputStatistics
member.summary:
Get streaming output statistics, such as the number of primitives streamed out in between DeviceContext.Begin and DeviceContext.End. DeviceContext.GetData will return a QueryDataStreamOuputStatistics structure.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_QUERY_SO_STATISTICS)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.OcclusionPredicate
member.summary:
Similar to Occlusion, except DeviceContext.GetData returns a BOOL indicating whether or not any samples passed the depth and stencil tests - TRUE meaning at least one passed, FALSE meaning none passed.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_QUERY_OCCLUSION_PREDICATE)

Similar to Occlusion, except Asynchronous.GetData returns a BOOL indicating whether or not any samples passed the depth and stencil tests - TRUE meaning at least one passed, FALSE meaning none passed.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_OCCLUSION_PREDICATE)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.PipelineStatistics
member.summary:
Get pipeline statistics, such as the number of pixel shader invocations in between DeviceContext.Begin and DeviceContext.End. DeviceContext.GetData will return a QueryDataPipelineStatistics.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_QUERY_PIPELINE_STATISTICS)

Get pipeline statistics, such as the number of pixel shader invocations in between Asynchronous.Begin and Asynchronous.End. Asynchronous.GetData will return a QueryDataPipelineStatistics.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_PIPELINE_STATISTICS)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.TimestampDisjoint
member.summary:
Determines whether or not a Timestamp is returning reliable values, and also gives the frequency of the processor enabling you to convert the number of elapsed ticks into seconds. DeviceContext.GetData will return a QueryDataTimestampDisjoint. This type of query should only be invoked once per frame or less.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_QUERY_TIMESTAMP_DISJOINT)

Determines whether or not a Timestamp is returning reliable values, and also gives the frequency of the processor enabling you to convert the number of elapsed ticks into seconds. Asynchronous.GetData will return a QueryDataTimestampDisjoint. This type of query should only be invoked once per frame or less.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_TIMESTAMP_DISJOINT)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Timestamp
member.summary:
Get a timestamp value where DeviceContext.GetData returns a UINT64. This kind of query is only useful if two timestamp queries are done in the middle of a TimestampDisjoint query. The difference of two timestamps can be used to determine how many ticks have elapsed, and the TimestampDisjoint query will determine if that difference is a reliable value and also has a value that shows how to convert the number of ticks into seconds. See QueryDataTimestampDisjoint. When using this type of query, DeviceContext.Begin is disabled.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_QUERY_TIMESTAMP)

Get a timestamp value where Asynchronous.GetData returns a UINT64. This kind of query is only useful if two timestamp queries are done in the middle of a TimestampDisjoint query. The difference of two timestamps can be used to determine how many ticks have elapsed, and the TimestampDisjoint query will determine if that difference is a reliable value and also has a value that shows how to convert the number of ticks into seconds. See QueryDataTimestampDisjoint. When using this type of query, Asynchronous.Begin is disabled.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_TIMESTAMP)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Occlusion
member.summary:
Get the number of samples that passed the depth and stencil tests in between DeviceContext.Begin and DeviceContext.End. DeviceContext.GetData returns a UINT64. If a depth or stencil test is disabled, then each of those tests will be counted as a pass.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_QUERY_OCCLUSION)

Get the number of samples that passed the depth and stencil tests in between Asynchronous.Begin and Asynchronous.End. Asynchronous.GetData returns a UINT64. If a depth or stencil test is disabled, then each of those tests will be counted as a pass.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_OCCLUSION)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Event
member.summary:
Determines whether or not the GPU is finished processing commands. When the GPU is finished processing commands DeviceContext.GetData will return S_OK, and pData will point to a BOOL with a value of TRUE. When using this type of query, DeviceContext.Begin is disabled.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_QUERY_EVENT)

Determines whether or not the GPU is finished processing commands. When the GPU is finished processing commands Asynchronous.GetData will return S_OK, and pData will point to a BOOL with a value of TRUE. When using this type of query, Asynchronous.Begin is disabled.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_QUERY_EVENT)

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.MessageCategory
member.summary:
Categories of debug messages. This will identify the category of a message when retrieving a message with InfoQueue.GetMessage and when adding a message with InfoQueue.AddMessage. When creating an info queue filter, these values can be used to allow or deny any categories of messages to pass through the storage and retrieval filters.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_MESSAGE_CATEGORY)

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.Map
member.summary:
Identifies a resource to be accessed for reading and writing by the CPU. Applications may combine one or more of these flags.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_MAP)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.WriteNoOverwrite
member.summary:
Resource is mapped for writing; the existing contents of the resource cannot be overwritten. This flag is only valid on vertex and index buffers. The resource must have been created with write access (see ). Cannot be used on a resource created with the ConstantBuffer flag.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_MAP_WRITE_NO_OVERWRITE)

Resource is mapped for writing; the existing contents of the resource cannot be overwritten. This flag is only valid on vertex and index buffers. The resource must have been created with write access (see ). Cannot be used on a resource created with the ConstantBuffer flag.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_MAP_WRITE_NO_OVERWRITE)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.WriteDiscard
member.summary:
Resource is mapped for writing; the previous contents of the resource will be undefined. The resource must have been created with write access (see ).
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_MAP_WRITE_DISCARD)

Resource is mapped for writing; the previous contents of the resource will be undefined. The resource must have been created with write access (see ).
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_MAP_WRITE_DISCARD)

member.summary:

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.FilterType
member.summary:
Types of magnification or minification sampler filters.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_FILTER_TYPE)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Linear
member.summary:
Bilinear interpolation filtering used as a texture magnification or minification filter. A weighted average of a 2 x 2 area of texels surrounding the desired pixel is used. The texture filter to use between mipmap levels is trilinear mipmap interpolation. The rasterizer linearly interpolates pixel color, using the texels of the two nearest mipmap textures.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_FILTER_TYPE_LINEAR)

Bilinear interpolation filtering used as a texture magnification or minification filter. A weighted average of a 2 x 2 area of texels surrounding the desired pixel is used. The texture filter to use between mipmap levels is trilinear mipmap interpolation. The rasterizer linearly interpolates pixel color, using the texels of the two nearest mipmap textures.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_FILTER_TYPE_LINEAR)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.SingleThreaded
member.summary:
Use this flag if an application will only be calling D3D11 from a single thread. If this flag is not specified, the default behavior of D3D11 is to enter a lock during each API call to prevent multiple threads altering internal state. By using this flag no locks will be taken which can slightly increase performance, but could result in undefine behavior if D3D11 is called from multiple threads.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_CREATE_DEVICE_SINGLETHREADED)

Create a single-threaded device.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_CREATE_DEVICE_SINGLETHREADED)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.DoNotFlush
member.summary:
Do not flush the command buffer. This can potentially cause an infinite loop if GetData is continually called until it returns S_OK as there may still be commands in the command buffer that need to be processed in order for GetData to return S_OK. Since the commands in the command buffer are not flushed they will not be processed and therefore GetData will never return S_OK.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_ASYNC_GETDATA_DONOTFLUSH)

Do not flush the command buffer. This can potentially cause an infinite loop if GetData is continually called until it returns S_OK as there may still be commands in the command buffer that need to be processed in order for GetData to return S_OK. Since the commands in the command buffer are not flushed they will not be processed and therefore GetData will never return S_OK.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_ASYNC_GETDATA_DONOTFLUSH)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Point
member.summary:
The data is organized in a point list.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_PRIMITIVE_POINT)

Point filtering used as a texture magnification or minification filter. The texel with coordinates nearest to the desired pixel value is used. The texture filter to be used between mipmap levels is nearest-point mipmap filtering. The rasterizer uses the color from the texel of the nearest mipmap texture.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_FILTER_TYPE_POINT)

Point filtering used as a texture magnification or minification filter. The texel with coordinates nearest to the desired pixel value is used. The texture filter to be used between mipmap levels is nearest-point mipmap filtering. The rasterizer uses the color from the texel of the nearest mipmap texture.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_FILTER_TYPE_POINT)

The data is organized in a point list.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_PRIMITIVE_POINT)

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.Direct3D11.DriverType
member.summary:
Driver type options.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D_DRIVER_TYPE)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Warp
member.summary:
A WARP driver, which is a high-performance software rasterizer. The rasterizer supports all current feature levels (level 9.1 through level 11.0) with a high performance software implementation when hardware is not available. For more information about using a WARP driver, see Windows Advanced Rasterization Platform (WARP) In-Depth Guide
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D_DRIVER_TYPE_WARP)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Software
member.summary:
A software driver, which is a driver implemented completely in software. The software implementation is not intended for a high-performance application due to its very slow performance.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D_DRIVER_TYPE_SOFTWARE)

Reserved for later use.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_DRIVER_TYPE_SOFTWARE)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Null
member.summary:
A NULL driver, which is a reference driver without render capability. This driver is commonly used for debugging non-rendering API calls, it is not appropriate for retail applications. This driver is installed by the DirectX SDK.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D_DRIVER_TYPE_NULL)

A NULL device; which is a reference device without render capability.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_DRIVER_TYPE_NULL)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Reference
member.summary:
A reference driver, which is a software implementation that supports every Direct3D feature. A reference driver is designed for accuracy rather than speed and as a result is slow but accurate. The rasterizer portion of the driver does make use of special CPU instructions whenever it can, but it is not intended for retail applications; use it only for feature testing, demonstration of functionality, debugging, or verifying bugs in other drivers. This driver is installed by the DirectX SDK. This driver may be referred to as a REF driver, a reference driver or a reference rasterizer.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D_DRIVER_TYPE_REFERENCE)

A reference device; commonly called a REF device.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_DRIVER_TYPE_REFERENCE)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Hardware
member.summary:
A hardware driver, which implements Direct3D features in hardware. This is the primary driver that you should use in your Direct3D applications because it provides the best performance. A hardware driver uses hardware acceleration (on supported hardware) but can also use software for parts of the pipeline that are not supported in hardware. This driver type is often referred to as a hardware abstraction layer or HAL.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D_DRIVER_TYPE_HARDWARE)

A hardware device; commonly called a HAL device.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_DRIVER_TYPE_HARDWARE)

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.MonitorInfo.WorkCoordinates
member.summary: Specifies the work area rectangle of the display monitor that can be used by applications, expressed in virtual-screen coordinates. Windows uses this rectangle to maximize an application on the monitor. The rest of the area in MonitorRect contains system windows such as the task bar and side bars. Note that if the monitor is not the primary display monitor, some of the rectangle's coordinates may be negative values.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.MonitorInfo.MonitorCoordinates
member.summary: Specifies the display monitor rectangle, expressed in virtual-screen coordinates. Note that if the monitor is not the primary display monitor, some of the rectangle's coordinates may be negative values.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.Luid
member.summary: A Luid is a 64-bit value guaranteed to be unique only on the system on which it was generated. The uniqueness of a locally unique identifier (LUID) is guaranteed only until the system is restarted. An LUID is not for direct manipulation. Applications are to use functions and structures to manipulate Luid values.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.ResourcePriority
member.summary: Resource Priorities.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.MapOption
member.summary: CPU read-write flags. These flags can be combined with a logical OR.

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Write
member.summary:
Allow CPU write access.
(Also see DirectX SDK: DXGI_MAP_WRITE)

The resource is to be mappable so that the CPU can change its contents. Resources created with this flag cannot be set as outputs of the pipeline and must be created with either dynamic or staging usage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_CPU_ACCESS_WRITE)

Resource is mapped for writing. The resource must have been created with write access (see ).
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_MAP_WRITE)

The resource is to be mappable so that the CPU can change its contents. Resources created with this flag cannot be set as outputs of the pipeline and must be created with either dynamic or staging usage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_CPU_ACCESS_WRITE)

Resource is mapped for writing. The resource must have been created with write access (see ).
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_MAP_WRITE)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Read
member.summary:
Allow CPU read access.
(Also see DirectX SDK: DXGI_MAP_READ)

The resource is to be mappable so that the CPU can read its contents. Resources created with this flag cannot be set as either inputs or outputs to the pipeline and must be created with staging usage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_CPU_ACCESS_READ)

Resource is mapped for reading. The resource must have been created with read access (see ).
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_MAP_READ)

The resource is to be mappable so that the CPU can read its contents. Resources created with this flag cannot be set as either inputs or outputs to the pipeline and must be created with staging usage.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_CPU_ACCESS_READ)

Resource is mapped for reading. The resource must have been created with read access (see ).
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_MAP_READ)

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.MakeWindowAssociationFlags
member.summary: Flags for making window association with a surface.

member.name: F:<unknown type>.NoPrintScreen
member.summary:
Prevent DXGI from responding to a print-screen key.
(Also see DirectX SDK: DXGI_MWA_NO_PRINT_SCREEN)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.NoAltEnter
member.summary:
Prevent DXGI from responding to an alt-enter sequence.
(Also see DirectX SDK: DXGI_MWA_NO_ALT_ENTER)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.NoWindowChanges
member.summary:
Prevent DXGI from monitoring an applications message queue; this makes DXGI unable to respond to mode changes.
(Also see DirectX SDK: DXGI_MWA_NO_WINDOW_CHANGES)

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.SwapEffect
member.summary:
Options for handling pixels in a display surface after calling SwapChain.Present.
(Also see DirectX SDK: DXGI_SWAP_EFFECT)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Sequential
member.summary:
Use this flag to indicate that the contents of the back buffer are not discarded after calling SwapChain.Present. Use this option to present the contents of the swap chain in order, from the first buffer (buffer 0) to the last buffer. This flag cannot be used with multisampling.
(Also see DirectX SDK: DXGI_SWAP_EFFECT_SEQUENTIAL)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Discard
member.summary:
Use this flag to indicate that the contents of the back buffer are discarded after calling SwapChain.Present. This flag is valid for a swap chain with more than one back buffer, although, an application only has read and write access to buffer 0. Use this flag to enable the display driver to select the most efficient presentation technique for the swap chain.
(Also see DirectX SDK: DXGI_SWAP_EFFECT_DISCARD)

Discard the previous contents of a resource when it is mapped.
(Also see DirectX SDK: DXGI_MAP_DISCARD)

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.SwapChainFlag
member.summary:
Options for swap-chain behavior.
(Also see DirectX SDK: DXGI_SWAP_CHAIN_FLAG)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.GdiCompatible
member.summary:
Set this flag to enable an application to render using GDI on a swap chain or a surface. This will allow the application to call GetDC on the 0th back buffer or a surface.
(Also see DirectX SDK: DXGI_SWAP_CHAIN_FLAG_GDI_COMPATIBLE)

Enables a resource compatible with GDI.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D11_RESOURCE_MISC_GDI_COMPATIBLE)

Enables a surface to be used for GDI interoperability. Setting this flag enables rendering on the surface via Surface1.GetDC.
(Also see DirectX SDK: D3D10_RESOURCE_MISC_GDI_COMPATIBLE)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.AllowModeSwitch
member.summary:
Set this flag to enable an application to switch modes by calling SwapChain.ResizeTarget. When switching from windowed to full-screen mode, the display mode (or monitor resolution) will be changed to match the dimensions of the application window.
(Also see DirectX SDK: DXGI_SWAP_CHAIN_FLAG_ALLOW_MODE_SWITCH)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.NonPrerotated
member.summary:
Turn off automatic image rotation; that is, do not perform a rotation when transfering the contents of the front buffer to the monitor. Use this flag to avoid a bandwidth penalty when an application expects to handle rotation. This option is only valid during full-screen mode.
(Also see DirectX SDK: DXGI_SWAP_CHAIN_FLAG_NONPREROTATED)

Flags indicating the memory location of a resource.

At least some of the resource has been paged out to the hard drive.

Share the surface or resource.

Enables resource data sharing between two or more Direct3D devices. The only resources that can be shared are 2D non-mipmapped textures.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.DirectX.DXGI.PresentFlag
member.summary:
Options for presenting frames to the output.
(Also see DirectX SDK: DXGI_PRESENT)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.Test
member.summary:
Do not present the frame to the output. The status of the swapchain will be tested and appropriate errors returned. Test is only intended for use when switching from the idle state; do not use it to determine when to switch to the idle state as doing so can leave the swapchain unable to exit fullscreen mode.
(Also see DirectX SDK: DXGI_PRESENT_TEST)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.DoNotRestart
member.summary:
Discard pending presentations; for subsequent presentations, present a frame from each buffer (starting with the first buffer) to the output.
(Also see DirectX SDK: DXGI_PRESENT_RESTART)

member.name: F:<unknown type>.DoNotSequence
member.summary:
Present a frame from the current buffer to the output. Use this flag to exploit the vertical-blank synchronization during presentation, without sequencing the buffers in the chain as normal.
(Also see DirectX SDK: DXGI_PRESENT_DO_NOT_SEQUENCE)
